Each manager was different in their interpretation of the rules and how they managed. I knew of one who was a true autocrat in management style and "Jekyll-Hyde personality. review_title: Great place and great brand to work for
pros: A lot of good things here. Decent pay, good bonus, great financial services problems to solve and make an impact with your work in banking and consequently in business world. The management has amazing leaders at the top right from CEO to level 5. No wonder this company is growing leaps and bounds and making a big difference in financial services world.
cons: Work timings - With the overlap needed to work with US team it means most teams work from 12 PM to 9 PM ...which means by the time you get home, family is sleeping. For some people it doesn't matter, for some it does...for those who it does, it will impact your life in a non-subtle way. Figure out how you want to deal with it before you join. It means for 5 days your evenings are toast. But on the other hand it gives a lot of time at the start of the day to pursue your interests but the family is hardly at home during that time. That has been the only 1 big single con with this job.

review_title: My experience is strictly in the retail bank. You will definitely succeed if you are pleasantly unambitious.
pros: If you are inexperienced and open to learning the basics of sales this is a great starting point. You will learn scripted behaviors and banking regulations. If you are ok watching unskilled micromanagers coach employees to tears, you will enjoy working here.  There is opportunity to move laterally. There are branches everywhere.
cons: I speak only from my personal experience working in two branches. In my observation, the lower-to-middle management inhibits career growth in their employees. Most especially if the employee is an ambitious woman.  I compared my review with a male coworker and we found that he was described as assertive and I was abrasive in same situation. My year-end bonus (at manager's discretion) was less than half what my male coworker received, even though my sales were much higher than his. I've never experienced such bias. I knew it was not  just me when I looked at the management as a whole. I observed two women in district management positions (just two levels above me). Both had more than 20 years experience with the bank while the four men I met at that same level each had half that experience. I concluded the company was better suited to men. Although, unambitious, extremely pleasant young women would always find lower paid positions in support roles.

If you wanted to work in financial services, J.P. Morgan has a lot to offer. It certainly does not have the most aggressive culture within banking. Pay is in line with industry practices and might be slightly higher. For a lot of roles, because of the J.P. Morgan name you can access a lot of very good clients.
cons:
- Bureaucratic, opaque structure
- The usual bad things about banking
- The usual bad things about big corporates

To earn the very good salary, you sacrifice a lot of other things in life. Just like every other market transaction, equal is exchanged for equal. Fear of the unknown in a lower income lifestyle and greed for excessive financial security and freedom are the two reasons why people stay. If you want to learn and grow as much as you can, you could find yourself stuck a career bus that someone else is driving.

review_title: Great people and environment. Reasonably easy work for salary.

This would  incentivise EAs to work harder, reduce turnover and ultimately make EA's feel equal to others in the company.

review_title: A good place to start a career
pros:
JPM is a place where you can feel things happening at a high pace, and it feels good being part of it.
You also get to meet and work with quite a few smart and driven people, which also feels good.
All in all it is a great place to start you career.
cons: Depending on location and team, you might end up in a "production" team (Operations, IT support...) where the only point is to get the most from you (extra hours and stress) until you cannot take it anymore and accept to move a different job of the same type (so-called rotations, often presented as promotions) or quit. But that must be true at many other firms.

pros: Time off is good. The benefits are so so. Pay can be good if negotiated up front. Nothing else is good.  Stay away if you want to keep your sanity and self respect.
cons: If you ever aspire to be even average DO NOT WORK HERE.   The world is going for automation, this place is in the dark ages. If you have any skill, do not think about it even for a second. The starting salary can be good but you will be miserable and it is not worth the price of admission.  I have no idea how they are going to attract a younger generation of techies. There is no flexibility and no work from home. Expected to be in the office for 40+ hours.  Way understaffed and a revolving door. If it were not for our good friends from India the company  would be hurting for skilled workers. I repeat DO NOT WORK HERE IF YOU ARE A TECHNOLOGY PROFESSIONAL. some things are not worth the sacrifice.

pros: if you are a hard worker you can advance in this company.  The company is so big that you have a lot of opportunity to move to a different field if the current one you are in is not for you.  Chase takes good care of its employees with benefits and a great 401k plan.
cons: Since the company is so big you can sometimes become a number if you do not have an amazing direct manager.  I have been lucky that is not the case for me.  Management is salary and that has been difficult for me being a working mom and working 50+ hours a week. A 20 hour teller gets the same amount of vacation time as a manager.  I dont feel this is fair as management works so many more hours.  Salary isnt very high for management, to make good money you really need to be a top performer to bonus out high.

pros:
- Some really great colleagues who are actually there to achieve goals with you
- good place to while away the time without achieving anything 
- firm still has a good reputation to those not in the know so being able to put it on your CV still helps.
cons:
- very top heavy. My unit of around 60 people only had 2 people who were AVP's. The rest were all MD, ED & VP. Most MD & ED just presented work done by the VP's and AVP's. You will find the same piece of work 'presented' over and over again as though it was done by 20 people! For me as a VP I was working really hard but getting no recognition.
- MD's keep telling me they are here just to feed their families, not to do real work. It's hard to feel a sense of belonging unless it's your career ambition to do nothing at work!
- very political at the top. Definitely being bright and working hard is not the way to the top. Hard to find people you can respect at senior levels.
- extremely bureaucratic. Be prepared to argue against the status quo and the old ways of doing things. Even simple decisions take years and there's a lot of procrastination at the senior levels to move things forward.

review_title: Room to grow but upper management is constantly changing things and setting unrealistic expectations
pros: Great Pay and benefits, 401K, paid time off etc.  Very professional company and number one priority is customer service.
cons: Upper management is constantly changing the way you are supposed to do your job every single day.  And I do mean every single day, that is not an exaggeration.  Heavily micro managed and unrealistic expectations.  I am someone that takes pride in my work, and at the end of the day I would leave every night just barely making my numbers by the skin of my teeth because the requirement was barely possible.  I started feeling like I was not good at my job anymore.  The stress level was off the charts.  Training classes for new procedures every single day which took away from work time but you are still expected to make your numbers.   High turnover rates for employees due to stress.  Was laid off in 2013 and I was actually relieved.  Sad.

Having the dignity to represent the company was always great.  Company has pretty good health/dental/ 401k/Stock profit-sharing and for the most part, have a life-work balance experience.  (RETAIL)

pros: They had a very flexible schedule while I was a student. They also paid better than any student job that was on-campus. When I started doing the job full-time, it was still a joy to do. You get paid holiday and vacation time, every sunday and federal holiday off, etc. It is a great place to start to gain valuable customer service skills and cash-handling experience.
cons: The only 'con' I can think about is that you have to be super vigilant about fraud, and it can at times make you a bit paranoid. You wouldn't believe how many people try to cash fake checks, hand in fake money, or try to pose as someone else. You get better at identifying fake items with more time on the job.

review_title: Put in your time and kiss up to management.
pros: Bank hours are great, even though our branch was open until 4pm on Saturdays.. meaning you don't get out until 430pm. Can save money on memberships at Costco, 24 hour fitness, Verizon, etc. You can really grow your career in the company if you work hard and put your time in.

It is career oriented but depending of the areas that you are working, in operations you feel a bit stagnated but in investment banking and project management you have support and a guarantee of a successful career.
cons:
Not easy to get promoted in must of the areas and management are not very cooperative many times, or supportive.
There are also some discrepancy in terms of salary within the same department which I don't think to be very fair.

pros:

Numerous company events advertised on intranet.
cons:
"Associate's" appear to have been shoehorned into these roles with little or no people management skills. Get the impression that if a situation arises that doesn't appear in the managers handbook then they have no idea how to deal with it. 
Extremely cliquey atmosphere, get the impression that the company has blanket hired a number of staff with little or no plan on how to integrate them into the company or make them feel welcome. Very bland corporate atmosphere, get the impression that the majority of staff think they're one promotion away from a starring role in The Apprentice. Embarassing self promotion of "graduates" on company emails (is anyone genuinely interested in Ben traveling round the word with his backpack?) & constant emailing bigging up JP Morgan that leaves you with the impression that they're trying to convince themselves that it's a good place to be.
