Not a place for IT employees to grow professionally. The company outsources projects to external vendors with novice developers for cheap rates. At the same time it shifts own crews to do support and cleanup of the mess done by the outsourcing companies.
A lot of time is wasted on bureaucratic procedures and meeting about other meetings.
Very conservative environment in IT - the bank does not adopt or adopts very slowly new methodologies and technologies.
Recent acquisitions resulted in the IT infrastructure being a mix of all kinds platforms and applications, some of them very old or in-house grown. The bank wastes a lot of time and money on IT support because of very flawed and improperly done system integrations that followed acquisitions.
Lack of enforcing good programming practices and enterprise architecture standards in IT. Inclination to ad-hoc, cheap and poor quality technical solutions in applications development. 
The exempt employees work a lot of (unpaid) overtime - the environment is far from the decent work-life balance.

review_title: The Grass is Greener on the Other Side
pros: Benefits are top notch and lots of learning opportunities within AML.
cons: No room for advancement -- you can try your hardest to kiss their butt, however, there is no guarantee and they ALWAYS play favorites! Mandatory OT -- REALLY?!?!....Do I need to say more? When you have children to take care of -- the kids come 1st! It's all about QUOTA!! You need to do at least 6-8 per day which you may think is easy peasy until you work a bundle of 2, 3, or 4 and then you are scrambling to no end. JP Morgan's training for AML is a complete JOKE! 2 weeks of training and 1 week of a side by side and then you are thrown to the wolves...its either sink or swim. Your colleagues may be helpful at first and then they will go behind your back and tell your manager that you aren't up to par on the game. Do not trust your fellow co-workers  or your manager! Better yet -- do not trust anyone! Working in the White Clay office in DE is like stepping into the morgue! Do yourself a favor and go somewhere where its happy and less anal retentive!

pros: Best support services like cabs

review_title: Overall - proud, rewarding, great peers, very hard working
job_title: Risk Management I T Project Manager in City of London, England
pros:
1.  High salary.  Excellent Health Care, excellent pension scheme, benefits package.
2.  Great peer working relationships
3.  Interesting projects, learning on the job opportunities, good training options
cons:
1.  Lack of exposure to Senior Management.  Management struggle to find time to listen
2.  Blame culture.  Silos's still exist.
3.  'Jack of all trades' perception in job title prevents acceptance of and dedication to specific skillets i.e. Project Management.  In this example, BA's tend to get lumped with PM role, which impacts delivery (negatively).  JPM should go back to separating roles and responsibilities.  They have the funds to allow this!!

pros:
Exposure to global projects and latest tech, hands on coding but that purely depends on your luck.
Decent pay and great bonuses for freshers.
Sodexos, transportation.
No in out timings.
Generally the teams are nice - of many I've worked with.
cons:
Lack of mentorship & direction for freshers - again depends on team.

People in your team may not be enthusiastic about delivering quality code with 0 defects and 0 rework that somehow may decrease your motivation to work with your full potential.

Not so definite set of goals/KPI which can lead to surprises during your appraisal.

A developer who's not interested in automation or manual testing HAS to do it, a QA who is experienced only in QA might have to do development. 

Many of other teams I know don't have dedicated BAs. 


Dependency on counter parts team lead to late nighters.

pros:
-Associates start with 4 weeks paid vacation on top of personal days and sick time
-6 weeks paid leave for new fathers
cons:
-The shareholder comes first = company culture
-Dept employees are not being replaced due to increased outsourcing and  automation
-No career opportunities in this dept (must look outside of dept)
-Employees are frequently moved around. It is not uncommon to have a half-dozen different managers over a 3 year time period
-Working remotely is generally discouraged unless employee is putting in extra hours
-The bonus & raise pool gets smaller each year
-401k match only happens once a year. If you leave before it gets paid out, you lose it
-Many of the HR services have been outsourced. The answers you get are often inconsistent

pros: You have a job.  You have a job.  You have a job.  You have a job.  You have a job.  Wash, rinse, and repeat.
cons:
You leave dumber before you came into the company.  PMC/Performance Management Central is a joke.  HR is just a suicide prevention hotline.  A new fire drill everyday.  Innovation is stifled.  People are not accountable for their actions.  People got away with being shluffs.  WM, CCB, and CIB (in order of increasing idiocy) were the biggest bunch of idiots I worked with.  When tempers flare, the CIO would come in to calm the waters.  Extremely poor hiring practices.  Company would do things just to get folks to leave and not have to pay severance.  You are monitored when you enter or leave a building, when you go to the cafeteria, when you print, if you work remote, as you walk to and from your car.  Everything is watched.  

You are just a standard ID.  Run...run as fast as you can away from this place and don't look back.  "Chase what matters!"

review_title: Must Sell your soul to the Company
pros: Chase is a very powerful and strong name which brings along a great amount of benefits for that reason.   The company is financially viable and willing to spend money where it can see a good reason.
cons: Managers and above are expected to bleed Chase.  It must be the most important thing in your life.  Do not expect that your family life outside of work is more imporant than what Chase needs even if that means unplanned late Sunday night meetings to talk strategy on something that could have been discussed the next day.   Also be ready for layers of red tape in order to get simple things accomplished.  There are so much division of labor to the point that it would take a team of 20 people to accomplish the simple task of providing instuctions for someone to tie their shoe.

review_title: Not a place for the honest and multi-tasked/ skilled individuals
pros: A good company who can rapidly expand its footprint and provide employment at low cost labour.
cons:
Ongoing poor management
•	There is clear poor understanding and poor realistic calculation of the amount of time available in comparison to the workload that needs to be completed by individuals and team as a whole.
•	The amount of times where valid concerns/ issues have been (re)addressed to management and end up being dismissed is horrendous.
•	There is clear lack of 2 way feedback and professional skills. Management will refuse to address issue(s) for their personal benefit, leaving this at your own expense which also creates imbalance emotional power at workplace. 
•	Management is incapable of multitasking or work out efficiently who has done what or when. This provides unfair working condition to employees/ team members where managers fail to recognise individuals’ true potentials and achievements, and individuals have to keep duplicating time and efforts when addressing matters or answering queries to managers. 
•	Lack of diversity and understanding of various different background of people

review_title: Latest tech, need imporvement in culture
pros:
- The tech stack is mostly latest, so interesting to work. Some LOBS started working on cloud too.
- Anyone can take initiatives and move ahead with a good career
- Good option of internal transfer, if work becomes monotonous
- Pay is average
cons:
- because growth is all about visibility, lot of politics to be visible. 

For this some stay in office most of the times, shield others from interacting with POs and decision makers. So even if there are many good ppl in team, these visibility seekers eat up all benefits. 
Others cant match them, because of the work-life balance issue and prefer to leave the company.

review_title: Lots of politics in JP Morgan
pros: Good organisation, depends on the team you work with.
cons:
I was force to resign from the organisation because of politics. They extended my probation period with silly reasons. Then they gave me written exam on process, after four continues attempts, taught by one person and evaluation done by the same person, still didn’t clear the exam. Reason: grammatically errors etc... 
After the exam, in meeting along with the HR, manager threatens me that I will be terminated if I don’t resign myself (for not clearing the test).

The fact is that I heard the Vice President of the Team saying clearly that I wanted this person to get rid off and do whatever it takes after I denied to move to morning shift for few months. I heard this from outside the meeting room. Then one by one they made reason for extending the probationary period, followed by written test, followed by forced resignations.

What happened to the core values:
“Integrity”

review_title: No place to move up; a person being hired in can make more than one that has been there for several years.
pros: Great insurance. Office culture adequate.
cons: Too many chiefs, not enough indians.  Work was slowing down but they expect you to look busy and do nothing.  Favoritism runs rampant, there is a lot of reverse discrimination in the company.  People being hired in make more than those that have been there for years and upper management will not change that.  For the last several years, the increases were maximum 2%.  Training is almost non-existent.

review_title: Huge company with lots of opportunity
pros: Given the size of the organization, there is an abundance of opportunities.  Mobility is generally valued and supported by upper management.
cons: The flip-side of the above is that it can be very challenging to navigate such a huge organization.  Also, having worked there for over a decade, I've felt that over the last 3-4 years the increasing compliance and regulation has made it a more challenging place to enjoy working, depending on your particular role - certainly some jobs are not impacted to the same degree (for instance if you're not client-facing).  There is such a compliance and regulatory focus these days that it's amazing that any client business ever actually gets done any more.

review_title: Frustrating for self-motivated devs, but easy-ride if you wish to coast
pros:
- Big company/finance sector perks

- Mostly good, friendly, genuine people

- Great campus and facilities

- Easy to transfer internally
cons:
- Heavy bureaucracy and politics to wade through

- Lots of annual review/bonus driven people. Therefore lots of one-upmanship and power grabs

- Easy to get trampled on if you don't have a backbone. 

- Mostly in-house software and processes, with non-transferrable skills to learn

- Very short-term focused delivery. Tech debt is accumulated very quickly in order to appease higher ups and annual reviews

- Technical stacks and projects are very set in their ways, but with enough immature tech thrown in the mix to become a nightmare

- Lack of T-shaped devs, very much I-shaped (poor broad technical knowledge, good in narrower areas)

- Poor Agile/Scrum implementation. Severe lack of POs/BAs. Often used as an excuse rather than a planning tool ("Remember, we're agile")

- Pressure to be in the office more than core hours, even if nothing more to be done

pros:
- high performers will be treated well--the company is passionate about mobility and retaining talent, so even if a team ceases to exist, good people will be helped out and moved
- geographic mobility--JPM has offices all around the world, and I know of several people that have been able to spend a few years abroad (or indefinitely if they so choose) either at a similar role or within something different
- compensation is at par with other BBs (with a more supportive culture)
- corporate discounts are a nice perk--phone, museums, travel, etc
cons:
- review process can compress a person into whatever they are able to project on the senior leaders of the floor (in S&T) and the process can feel political and enforces certain behavior (instead of just doing a good job and focusing on ways to improve processes, image must be maintained)
- industry overall is compressing, so the trend here, as across the street, is to function as a leaner org (and the compression has negative consequences on comp and general sentiment)

pros: There was good pay, and always some friendly colleagues available to help you out should you have any problems.
cons:
Getting an offer seemed very dependent on what team you were put into at the beginning of the internship, and your manager. You're basically compared against each other as an intern, although an experienced manager may also compare you to the rest of his/her team. I was also asked to implement parts of a system which was later taught to me in year 3 at university, meaning I hadn't seen it before but was still judged upon it.
Also found you're unofficially expected to work until around 6pm minimum. It feels bad leaving before the rest of the team does...
In a skype call, the CEO told interns that their chances of getting an offer wouldn't be affected by Brexit, although later on a HR lady said there was "a higher bar set this year, meaning less offers would be given".

review_title: Really good for getting your feet wet in the corporate pool.
pros:
- Ability to learn about different departments in the financial industry.

- Good networking opportunities with the company directory and mentoring programs offered.

- Great benefit packages. 

-  There is plenty of room for growth - if you take advantage of the networking opportunities.

- Pay can be good for some - given that you negotiate properly.
cons:
- Lots of business cuts. You stop feeling like you matter as an employee and that you are just a number.

- Office politics and drama - at least in the department/building of my location. Very hard to move around without dropping rose petals for the right person. 

- Takes a lot to get a pay raise if you've been there for a while. At least it did with me. Shouldn't have to be that hard if you get promoted.

- Difficulty transferring from within. Recruiters would rather hire externally than from within.

pros:
Ability to work globally with smart, engaging colleagues 
Terrific Customers requiring complex products and support in a competitive environment
cons: Too focused on cutting costs, resulting in short term quick wins that are eroding depth and talent.  Difficult to have "work / life" balance.  Mobility at senior levels is difficult in middle or back office support areas.

pros: Good amount of time off and availability of flex schedule.
cons: Pay is not competitive, which is pretty ironic, considering the amount of mass emails about growing profits.  Micromanagement gets overbearing at times. Aside from customer service, the goals are not clearly defined and the management does not openly share the reports. Coaching solely revolves around errors. Management is afraid of challenging upward. No opportunity to work remotely. The upper management is continuously postponing this initiative, citing security issues.

review_title: Do not work for default department.
pros: Provided me foot in the door to the corporate world. Grateful for the opportunity, but it was not a pleasant journey from the mass hiring in 2011 to the mass layoff in 2013. Heard great things about all other departments at Chase. This review only reflects employment in the default sector of Chase.
cons:
Department was completely unorganized and at times very unprofessional. Glad to say most of the individuals that contributed to the negative image of the department either quit or were terminated after a massive complaint session from employees in 2012 (potential class action lawsuits). 

The department never had a chance to really rebuild from the mess previous management and certain individuals created. Ultimately, multiple California sites will be shut down and relocated to other locations throughout the U.S. by 2014. 

Too many changes and confusion within the job functions. Example 1: Inexperienced individuals placed on customer care calls without proper training which in turn provided customers with horrible service. Example 2: Ask 3 people in management a question and you will receive 3 different answers. Seems company's way to handle everything is "quick fix" solutions which only create bigger problems in the end. Makes you wonder how other financial institutions are being ran...

review_title: Great place to work if you join the company at good pay.
pros: JPMC Sevices India pvt ltd is good place to work where you best class infrastructure in place and good exposure when you joun the company on better pay.Company is very dedicated  towards the employees safety and betterment.JP Morgan highly emphasise on all round communication factor.
cons:
The saddest thing about JPMorgan India pvt ltd is  that they dont have transparency in terms of pay,bonus and recognition to deserving people.
Those who joined the company in India before 2005 are the luckiest chaps. HR as well as management is not clear about what the pay should be given to the employees based on Job description. Promotions and recognitions are 50% biased on racism.HR does'nt practise Industry standard pays.LOB heads showcase in there achivements for low costing part for low pay of employee.infact it is tool to exploit the employees.
Uncertainity of job due to process migration or process getting disbandoned.

pros: Uncapped incentives, benefits are OK at best
cons: Where to begin... Management transitioning to getting customers out of the branch and using ATMs. They've literally fired half of our branch staff (tellers, ABMs, SSAs). Job security is non-existent at this company. At a moments notice, you could get a letter stating your job is on the chopping block. They don't care about their employees any longer.. It's seriously all about cutting expenses and using whoever they have to suck every deposit and investment out of affluent clients. It's pathetic. No investment in their employees. They supposedly offer "tuition reimbursement" but no manager will approve it because their branch will have to pay for it, this risking their bonuses. Pay raises are non-existent although this is a financial institution who understands inflation quite well. If you're looking for a job, LOOK ELSEWHERE. Everyone I know at the company is quitting. And with good reason.

review_title: Not a place if looking for exciting, challenging growth opportunities
pros:
Standard stability as a large wirehouse
Some great leaders who are visionary , reasonable, open
minded and fast in change
cons:
Too many games and politics to play in order to get things done. Conversations are often led to circles and takes rounds of convo even to find the right people to speak to.
Too hierarchical, people talk to the title rather to the person.
Inconsistent quality of middle and lower staff, you can find some really mediocre managers and staff.
Takes long and a lot of politics to get promoted.
No encouragement or sponsorship to continued skillset upgrades and professional trainings.
Cliche mindset of “we are JPM, this is not how we do things...” where the disrupters are already at the front door.
A lot of obsolete people and roles.

pros:
The benefits package is top notch, 4 weeks vacation, personal time, etc.
Some good people/managers who try to do the right thing regardless of the obstacles thrown in front of them.  If you luck out and get in a team that has a decent command structure, there is room for advancement and expansion of your skillsets.
cons: Cronyism, politics, and silo'd teams are rampant, so good luck trying to find out anything out about the other departments you work with, especially if there is an issue.  Management is a joke as they are constantly rotating in and out and only reactionaries seem to be promoted, which leads everyone to chasing the fire of the moment.  Burnouts are extremely common and tolerated as management believes they can just throw more bodies into the mix until things level out.

pros: Very little to be proud of.  The offshore experiment seems to be failing miserably.  Communication has gotten worse over the years.  There are no tasks being performed by offshore that can't be done as well or  better by US  college level students.
cons: Management  unable to implement large projects.  Huge wastes of dollars on  'vision' that never goes anywhere.  Have seen tens of millions up in smoke.  Approach seems to be shake the box so people won't notice how little the managers actually accomplish.   every time you think things have to be settling down something new comes along to blow that out of the water.  Tactic is to get rid of or alienate all the people that truly know the business then start critical projects  doomed to be late or buggy.

review_title: 1 of my best decisions was to join J.P.Morgan.
pros:
So far so good. I have been getting more than I had asked for- Be it quality of work , quantity of work, hike in percentage, appreciation/ recognition,  Annual bonus or the annual remuneration.
-  Real Handsome Bonus - best in IB.  Sometimes 40% of your annual pay. 
- Job security best in IB industry.
- Chance to work on new Technologies.
- Hard work is Recognized and Appreciated.
- Transparent practices & policies.
- Free transport.
- Subsidized meal. Nice Cafeteria.
- Lots of Internal opportunities.
- High ethics, values, culture.
cons:
Haven't really found much in a span of a little more than 1 year.

- Almost NO work/life balance. There is NO shortage of work. It takes a good while to figure out balancing your life and work unless you are a female employee.
- Almost NO attention on FUN filled activities. Very less Project events/Outings.
- No games in office. 
- Very less employee engagement

pros:
Nice name to have on your CV.
You don't need a highly selective finance master to join the bank. 
If you are motivated and a little bit clever and innovative, the first few promotions and opportunities are easy to get. 
Jobs rotation are really encouraged, so if you are bored of your job you can easily change.
cons:
Incredibly long recruitment process, can take up to months for an entry level job. 
Very high turnover, once you've spent 8 months in a team you are considered a senior team member and have to train 3 people per year.
The company is cutting expenses and would rather have you do massive (unpaid) overtime than hire additional employees. 
Expenses are being cut, but there are no consequences for bad employees, they stay in their jobs for years. 
Unclear promotion paths, with a hint of nespotism
Organization is split between very small teams of 4 to 7 people, creating a lot of supervising role for people to feel important. 
No innovation whatsoever.

review_title: Great benefits and ample time off but that's about it.
pros:
Great benefits
Nice campus with cafeteria, lounge and other perks
Ample vacation, sick and PTO time
Overtime available on occasion
Corporate discounts
Good starting pay
Lots of schedule options
cons:
Little opportunity for financial growth
Training is long and ultimately not effective. Most of what you do you will have to learn on the job. 
Lots of favoritism 
Incompetent managers seemed to be common.
Only about 50% of managers are trying to improve morale and promote a team environment.
Recruitment staff flat out lies to applications. Promised promotion potential is grossly exaggerated. 
Little job security.

review_title: It depends on what area you are in and who your boss is!
pros: Some areas of the bank Retail, Commercial, Corporate are great with great people and as long as you have a great boss you will have a great experience
cons: Other areas of the Bank are not so lovely. Even if you have a great boss the it may not help you.  It can be irritating to see people get pushed up the ladder that are just showing up while others bleed from the knuckles just to keep their footing

pros:
good resources                                                                                 
nice environment
cons:
hectic                                                                                         
no work life balance

pros: Benefits are great. Really that’s it.
cons: You are a standard ID.  This company doesn’t think twice about eliminating positions. Multi-billion dollar quarterly profits. And they still will eliminate you.  If your not part of the good old boy club you won’t matter.  Ignore all the empowering women advertising.  It’s a front.  The company has gotten too big to truly care for their employees.  I succeeded and exceeded in every role during my employment.  But in the end.  The good ole boy system wins.  When they celebrate opening new branches...it means others are losing their jobs. No new adds to staff.  So sad.  Lots of incredibly talented people have left. The company LOVES to re-invent the same job with a different title so they can eliminate employees.  And then they immediately turn around and start hiring trainees.  BTW they love to get rid of long term employees.  And in order to receive severance you have to sign a waiver not to sue.

pros: Flexible, dynamic, wide exposure, business driven, have the mentalities “always do the right thing” and “first class business in first class way”, nice colleagues from other departments, have a team work mindset, supportive teammates, good medical coverage
cons:
The company embraces diversity and inclusion, however these do not apply in Hong Kong. Colleagues try to mold you to fit in and follow their mentality. Those who do not give in are always end up in trouble, difficult to collaborate with them at work and being excluded in team activity, tantamount to bullying. 

Super bureaucratic, lots of procedures, tedious and strict operational process, stressful environment. The firm embraces innovation and change but management does not have the right mindset and culture to push ahead.

Political environment, you have to pay special attention when replying  emails. Often times people use it against you or put you in unfavourable situations.

pros:
Great Pay ..but varies drastically between locations  and verticals

Bonus structure is Good

Good place to work if you are in right Line of business

Managing multiple locations and travel opportunity locally

Lots of training opportunities

Philanthropy initiatives
cons:
Legacy/Rusty technology and slow to adopt to Industry standards

Zero onsite opportunity for India leads, You can lock your passports in locker for Good.

You will become chauffeur and tour guide for frequently visiting Global managers

 Too many fancy titles and Top heavy 

Hierarchy changes every fortnight.

All decisions taken from  American office , Rest of the local managers/leads are treated like dummies/duds

Offshore teams perform majority of work and rest of global locations sleep their day through.

You might be stuck in the same level for many years to come.

Need right connections/politics than skill-set/performance to move up..

pros: True general management experience is readily available at this company early in one's career.  The range of topics that you deal with as a manager is so vast that at times you cannot believe it.  The breath-taking level of scale and complexity at this company creates a steady flow of superb problem solving and general management challenges.  Indeed, these challenges are so plentiful that you will trip over them on the way in to work each day if you aren't careful.
cons:
(1) Everything is a priority, so nothing is a priority.  
(2) Far too many managers value speed over the end-product itself.  The company survives because the deep and experienced middle management veterans prevent the seniors and the noobs from making too many mistakes.  
(3) The pace is relentless.

pros: At the moment I can't really think of too many pros.
cons: There are a large number of big changes that are being made in terms of processes that feel as if they are designed to force people to quit in an attempt to avoid a mass layoff and potential subsequent lawsuit.  Rather than working through the changes in a logical manner they are being presented as "This is the new way, take it or leave it" and there is no explanation provided as to why the changes are happening.  Additionally, management has been consistently misleading their employees or even lying outright, making promises that they can't keep and causing their employees to feel abandoned, betrayed, and scared for their jobs.

pros: JPMorgan Chase is for anyone one right out of college or doesn't mind having other employees take your suggestion and make it there own.  They will insure your employment until they need to cut the budget then your position is being outsourced to India.  They do give you an awesome 401k match @ 5% but your salary is low compared to like positions, unless you know someone.
cons: Once you have accepted a job there with the agreed upon salary, if you get a promotion they are usually not willing to pay you for that position.  Rather they will increase your base pay, up to 7%.  The senior team is not that bright and really have nothing to contribute other than throwing people under the bus.

pros:
What a great organisation to work for. WOW!!!!. I am what I am because of the opportunities JPMC provided to me and the great managers I had.
I joined JPMC India in 2003 and left in 2009 end and when I joined we were just a bunch of 500 odd people. Saw the company grow in size to 10000+ by the time I left.
I worked in IT team and it was nothing but a second family for all of us, we were all knitted together and being in different organisations now, we are still in touch.
I actually had a "career" with JPMC and not just another "Job".
cons:
When the organisation grew in size, the management changed a lot and it became more and more frictional (still was better than my experiences prior to JPMC).
Policy consistency is what I feel is lacking with JPMC.
Lot of dotted line reporting, make room for "chamchagiri" and is somewhat ruining the otherwise excellent environment.

review_title: Good company with average career growth
pros: Culture, career growth, etc are department specific. You have to be careful on what you are getting into as the minimum period for mobility is 2 years in current role. The facilities are great and processes are refined. Cab facility available.
cons: Avoid CIB Tech - India if possible. Crappy management. So called management folks (all MDs, EDs and most VPs) call themselves 'India lead' and really have no role to play. They are active mainly during the yearly appraisal time and hikes/bonus is based on perception and feedback from the global folks than individual interaction. VPs who were hired for people management are suddenly being asked to be 'hands-on' and code. These are people who probably haven't seen code for last decade or so and are looking for 'workarounds' to get around the process.

pros: JPMorgan Chase is a huge organization and in general a great place to work for, flexible, and very professional. I would go back in a heartbeat to this company.Great culture and organizational values, lots of room for growth, and amazing benefits.
cons: disconnect from front line employees. Unsure of what is happening at communities or what service clients expect for high rent rates. Very little confidentiality. All communication goes through management pipeline, and little is distributed below. There seems to be a resentment toward the employees who manage the day to day as opposed to those in the corporate office. Geniuses and brainstormers are needed, but these jobs are 80% perspiration and 20% inspiration. There is a serious shortage of "perspirers" in an environment based on exclusion.

pros:
- Learn and use new technologies if you get opportunity to work on Re-Engineering project.
- Lots of Training and growth opportunity
- Lots of individual contributor roles and you are evaluated based on performance
- Strong in ethics and compliance, also care for career development.
cons:
If you get into a lobby of political business unit, your credits can be eat up by those people or your manager, and you cannot complain to HR Business partner as he is also a part of that. In such groups you will get promotions based on voluntary initiative in birthday celebrations within team and who praise their managers and support even in case when it is unethical. 

If you are getting E ratings in past project and promotion in past project within J P Morgan, still they can screw up your career in this kind of non-competent lobby.

Also some project may spoil your work life balance like anything, even if political non-competent lobby is absent.

review_title: Chase is a great place to learn to adapt to change.
pros: Chase draws top talent and provides decent opportunities to advance and grow your career. If you get a good manager, you can move up quickly in the organization. They also offer some great benefits not available at most companies (generous vacation, long term care, legal).
cons: Be prepared to work hard and know that pay does not always align with the responsibilities. It's hard to get proper training/cross training. Often times it's baptism by fire. Promotions are difficult unless you have a manager that is willing to mentor or promote you. Supervisors cannot give external work references for former employees.

pros: I realized JP is actually a pretty amazing company especially after i left and joined another firm, that is frankly just an horrifying experience.  JP is extremely transparent, if something goes wrong even the finger pointing is transparent.  They care about individual development and if they put you into a new role, the make sure you have all the training you need.  Everything is documented.  If you want to learn anything business related, they make sure they could get someone to share knowledge or teach you.  Peers are very nice, management at least they act nice.  Honestly it is a very pleasant working environment with lots of opportunities to learn
cons: The pay system is unfair, 1 person can earn almost double of his/ her teammate doing the same thing.  People hired from outside get the most, people growing from within suffers from very poor increment if any

pros:
- Very flexible working environment 
- Extensive training for out of school hires 
- Great pay for entry level employees
cons:
- No clear direction for young people in the company to build your career 
- Not much diversity as you get to the ED level cross gender and racial lines 
- Mundane and cyclical work 
- A lot of idle time 
- Wasn’t utilized well by my program of team(s) for all the skills I brought to the table 
- No transferable skills learned 
I wouldn’t recommend this job for someone out of college. You want to be in a company that nurtures your skills and talent versus being another number.  It is very easy to get sucked in to the amount they pay you opposed to accepted the company for face value.

review_title: Great company that understands change and consumers.
pros: Top of the line in customer service for a large bank.  Very advanced technology and the necessary security features that need to be included which is driving the banking of the future.  Hours are great and allows for a well-balanced work vs. personal life.  I have yet to find a branch with people that I didn't enjoy working with.
cons: Can be a little overboard on some risk assessment factors.  I feel that HR and some of the corporate sectors are very unwilling to understand situations from an objective standpoint which can be frustrating when trying to get answers or discuss personal concerns.

review_title: They make it sound like a great job but it’s not
pros: Benefits are probably the only good thing
cons: Long hours, taking phone calls all day back to back with no time in between calls. It takes at least a year to move out of the customer service department but it’s not guaranteed you will get promoted. You are just another number here, they don’t care about you. If you need to call off work or have kids good luck, you always have to have some type of “segment” scheduled whether that be vacation, sick or personal time. This job is not very conducive for people with families. They score you on 4 different categories on your score card and constantly are hounding you about your numbers. You also have to talk with a lot of angry/irritated customers and you have to bend over backwards to help them even though you don’t want to. Take my advice and don’t apply here, if you don’t like call center jobs or talking on the phone this is not the job for you!

review_title: Worst in Work life balance & management favoritism to few employees
pros:
This is a true and genuine review, You will feel same once u comes
> Growth on different technologies
> Good to go and work on any technology in the same team, outside team needs to face some interview.
>Pay scale is better then Service based companies
> Free cab and sodexo facility
> security for women employees
> office infrastructure is good and convenient for employees
cons:
> Work pressure  is too high
> No work life balance due to heavy work load
> VP favoritism to few employees
> Getting Promotions will be very complex
> No(Not at al) onsite positions(out of thousand may be 1 or 2 members may get processed  B1)
> No pay for extra working hours, only comp off if manger approves
> No Appreciations to the work u did.

review_title: Avoid working as an engineer at this place
pros: I thought money would be good at this place, since they are the ones who determine how much money to print. However, I realized that money is less compared to other places. If you really want to make a career in banking go where the money is, don't go in the direction of operations. This place knows how to suck the life out of you.
cons: There is no work life balance at all. They expect you to work round the clock. I was in a support role as an engineer in the field of computer networks and as my wife says, I did not have a life. Management just gives you lip service, nothing else, they don't really care about you or the work you do. As long as they don't get bothered they are good.

review_title: great place to work, esp. to start your career
pros:
- great people culture; investment banks in general are notorious for their harsh environment, the JPM is somewhat an outlier in this respect, for it's focus on a longer-term sustainability and "doing the right thing" also affects the relations culture and how people treat each other - friendly, helpful, teamworking
- some very bright people work here
- good place to learn how things should be organized - infrastructure, teamwork, etc (again due to the Bank's focus on "doing things right")
cons:
- not a good place to make a lot of money
- lack behind the competition in the tech innovations (FinTech, bigdata technologies, etc); although the company focus on innovation and creation, it is more successful in innovation in the traditional financial/economic areas (products, services, etc), it still behind the recent IT tech breakthroughs - it's just too big and too long-term oriented to react that fast for the fast paced IT innovation.

review_title: Consistently able to find new challenges and reap the benefits
pros: Evolving culture of flexible hours and dress arrangement, great investment in the technology that has only increased over the years, fantastic job rotation opportunities after you spend at least 1-2 years in a current role, some technology teams are really able to work with some of the bleeding edge stuff, great location and on site facilities (Bank Street), brilliant festivals happen within the building makes for a really nice atmosphere
cons: Too much red tape in light of tighter audit controls, if you get stuck in a bad team it can really come back to bite you as it will stall your career progression which will have a knock on effect at every promotion, if you get in the right time you can see salary grow immensely but these opportunities are hard to find (obviously), canteen is very expensive (Bank Street), you have to make the noise if you want to be noticed

pros:
-Decent CTC, bonus
-Decent cafeteria, daily meal coupon
-Free cab
cons:
Joining J.P.Morgan might be the biggest mistake of my life. First to start with recruiting HR's will introduce themselves as product based org but make no mistake they are nothing but a service based company with good benefits. If you are more into money, this is a place for you, but if you are passionate for software development with highest standards, stay away.

People here are only focused on delivery and making business happy at any expense. Its exactly similar to companies like TCS, CTS. In my short span, I have never seen anyone discussing and documenting design in length. I was quite shocked watching the quality of code.

Also productivity is measured not in terms of output but time you spend in your office. You are required to fill time sheet of 8 hours and expected to stay in 10 hours. Also one of the higher management plainly mentioned this is not a place for you if you want flexible timings.

What is most disappointing about it is unwillingness to change. Even if you have some suggestions for improvements, if something is working why change it.

review_title: It's got it's pluses and minuses
pros: Some good people, lots of resources (if you're on the right team) and you may get lucky and end up in a really great spot in the company. If you hit a sweet spot it can be a really great place to work.
cons: You may also end up with a joke of a manager who just got where they are because they "play the game" or latched onto another joke of a manager that has climbed their way up by doing nothing but trying to please their managers. Don't expect raises or bonuses... They don't really care about you AT ALL... but they'll pretend they do :)

pros: At JPM Chase there was a tremendous amount of growth. I enjoyed the different roles I held at Chase and the opportunity was always there. Chase is a great company to be employed by.
cons: Very few downsides at Chase. They have a very very strict policy for zero tolerance for an underwriter and at time that can be a little stressful. Trying to meet deadlines with the Department of Justice and and zero errors via quality check.

pros:
JP Morgan is a great firm to work with, great people, great platform, great exposure.
The company culture is superb and people are willing to teach you. The management is rather flat and there a lot that you can do.
cons: Being a back office analyst, the exposure is limited to the product/line you are working and the sight is restricted with few market insights. The mobility within finance departments are high but not other than that, which is pretty frustrating since people here are so competitive.

review_title: Been a great place to start as a fresher and grow to a positon of Team lead.
pros: Great work culture. Great guidance is provided at every level. Great initiatives are made to keep learning and keep the employees feel comfortable at work.
cons: You will get drowned thinking this company is the world. Depends on who you are, the company gives great leavel of comfort for people to be loyal and if you need lot of money is short time this is not the place. You need job satisfaction with moderate or on par salary with the market this is your spot.

review_title: Working under a bean counter can be suicide
pros: Chance to work hard on great projects, lots of room to improve things and be recognized for your efforts and knowledge
cons: I worked under a manager who was posted as a dept head so she could have a source to pay her salary and a "position" while doing corporate cleanup work for the top level mgmt.  She didn't know how to turn on her terminal but was in charge of computer staff.  OUch!  She was in charge of an award banquet for employees who had perfect attendance - an award 70 people got, yet in my performance review stated I was absent without an excuse.  AS you can see, she has a few loose screws, but she has an MBA and got accepted by upper mgmt.   This is the Peter Principle in action.  Wonder why I left?

pros:
In my initial review I was very positive about working here. 3 years later I have a very different view.

Well-known bank
A lot of intelligent people to learn from
Good benefits
Flexible working arrangements (WFH, different office locations, etc)
cons:
Salaries are sub-par and promotion pay equals inflation rate at 2% - that's all...So the best people don't stick around for long.
No transparency around compensation or promotions (employees at the same level within the same group and location can have £10-30k salary difference).
Some "top" managers are grandfathered in and are not top talent otherwise
Quality employees are becoming a dying breed
Mobility is not as advertised

review_title: Do your job, not more not less
pros: The company does provide stability, unless of course you happen to be part of a division that isn't returning the desired returns.  In that case you will likely be downsized, or you will be transferred to another division that ultimately is set to be sold off or terminated all together.
cons: Advancement does happen.  But it is a bit political.  Doing your job well is only part of the puzzle.  Being buddy-buddy with your upper manager and potentially those above them can provide you will benefits for upward movement.  If not, then you will likely be looking at the company jobs sites to try to find a donkey-kong way of moving up the company...sometimes lateral moves are needed in the hopes that it will lead to a way up from a new department/division or manager.

review_title: Hire overqualified people to do substandard work with no flexibility for employees
pros: Job security with the flexibility to change roles within the organisation. Market changes do not affect job security. Chances of firing people is extremely rare. Transport is free.
cons:
1. Highly underpaid as compared to industry standards
2. Minimal flexibility for employees- need to work in shifts (mostly overtime), no work from home option and leave policy is also very stringent
3. Quality of work is sub par but recruitment requirements are always high which is leads to job dissatisfaction
4. Very strict policies like prohibited usage of smartphone, restricted email access etc.
5. Most of the decisions are taken onshore so there is very less ownership and decision making power out of India
6. Required to follow US calender (or Asia/EMEA) instead of India calender so no off on Indian holidays
7. Management solely works for the onshore business partners and is always hesitant in raising concerns from the Indian employees in front of onshore partners solely because business comes from onshore

pros:
- There is constantly and consistently work to do
- Helpful and knowledgeable staff
- As an intern, I've gotten the opportunity to contribute significant portions to an existing project. I had to work for it, but it's happening. 
- Great management, at least in my experience. They all seem extremely competent and very interested in moving the company and its employees forward.
cons:
- JPMC's technology division isn't very forward-focused. A lot of the technology they use is fairly legacy at this point
- As much as I hate to say it... JP Morgan really wants to be a technology company. But they're not, and (barring any major shifts) will never be. The office reflects this "wannabe Techie" feel, and, at least to me, it feels fake.

review_title: Constant Change and lack of senior management direction
pros: Highly recognized firm with a decent work life balance.  They offer lots of training and the ability to develop new skills.  They are very advanced when it comes to technology and supporting employee desktops.
cons: Navigating the firm and getting recognized is very challenging.  Compensation is less than many other firms in the area and benefits are the best. The environment is every changing and lack of senior managements involvement creates a lot of rework.  Most of your day will be spent in meetings about having a meeting instead of actually working.  You may only get two hours of productivity before what should be the end of your day arrives.

pros:
Compensation package was excellent at all levels
Focused on hiring military veterans
Non-management employees were friendly and helpful.
cons:
Compensation had to be excellent because they averaged 25% turnover PER QUARTER while I was there.
Turnover was due to poor management practices that caused an unacceptable level of stress.
Bottom 80% in volume and quality were under heavy scrutiny to improve their numbers. Only the top 20% were left to do their jobs. Impossible to meet metrics due to management's ignorance of interpreting sample size and relevance of data.
Many of the promotions I saw were based on who was sleeping with who, or who they could promote that was unable to leave based upon their inability to get another job somewhere else.
Eventually ~80% of the staff was laid off or fired, including management.
Being promoted from within production is almost impossible, many coworkers were overqualified for the position but because of policy could not jump pay levels to positions they were qualified for.

review_title: Solid bluechip, good on business ethics but oh so slow to change
pros:
Generally the atmosphere is good , colleagues are helpful, hard working and dedicated. 

Good opportunities for an international career , if you are mobile.

Excellent training options , top class online skills academy.

Some stand out managers , who care for their people, deliver results and inspire
cons:
Non stop focus on cost cutting.

Global seniors always minding their patch, defensive unstable and highly political.

Its rare but some people get into management roles even when they bully and intimidate people 

Slowly developing the right approach to investing in  software but little real out of box thinking happening in that space

There is a subtle and inherent bias agaonst non native english speakers, no one is doing it intentionally but its there none the less

pros:
1. Free health check ups and monitoring. 
2. You will be alive at but broke if you ever get sick.
cons:
1. 1700 dollars copay + 1600 dollars OOP per person of the family. 
2. We did IFV, That's when I found out the loopholes. they will pay 80% of most procedures (NOT ALL) with restrictions on number of embryos, after your deductible and OOP is met. They will give you 10000 dollars lifetime amount for your IVF meds, BUT you will have to get it trough their contracted specialty pharmacy, where the price of the meds are astronomically insane (same med cost 200 dollars in India, 1200 in Fertility pharmacy, will cost 4800 dollars from Specialty pharmacy).  So, how far the 10k runs for your coverage? Yes, you wind up paying for your meds.
3. At the end the cost of IVF without insurance and with insurance, the difference is 0 dollars. (Trust me I have done it both)

review_title: Those who look to be associated with a brand and Job security, this is the place
job_title: Team Member, Tax Cost in Mumbai
pros:
Renowned across the industry for its brand
Very high in assets and big giant (company's worth is in Trillion Dollars)
Staff behaves some real professionalism
If someone wants to really learn about Finance, they should join JP Morgan in U.S. offices, in India, there is nothing really much to learn
There are relatively high chances of getting an immigration to U.S. offices in JP than its competitors
cons:
This may be for the process I worked for
Very monotonous job with no appreciation
Getting a promotion is very difficult, because employees don't leave JP and positions are never vacant
Very rigid about their current working methodologies and don't give values to innovation and ideas
A lot of work with very rare work life balance
Compensation too is also not as good as one would expect from a brand like JP

review_title: One of the worst places I've worked
pros:
Renovated the cafe
Good transport links to the office
cons:
Cliquey management 
Cliquey underlings
One of the most malicious environments I've ever worked in thoroughly encouraged by female management who see no wrong doing because they're doing it too
Heads of department complaining about their managers in the kitchens for the rest of the floor to hear
Overall the majority are two faced back stabbed out to spite each other
It's not competitive, it's not dog eat dog, its 2020 and a completely pathetic excuse for behaviour which is encouraged by those top down

review_title: Good pay & benefits, decent hours, lot of opportunities
pros:
- The base salary is competitive. Bonus can be good depending on who you work for
- The hours are decent and can widely vary depending on what LOB / department you're in
- JPMC really promotes internal mobility and given the size of the company, there are a lot of opportunities
- You can find some top talent in this company
cons:
- There's a lot of politics so be prepared
- There are many weak managers at the Executive Director level and VP level
- Managing Directors are often disconnected

review_title: High turnover of I.T. staff in London
job_title: Applications Developer in City of London, England
pros:
- Very good work/life balance
- Satisfactory compensation
- Business generally happy with products delivered.
- Little firefighting
cons:
- The past few years have seen a heavy restructuring of teams. Many people have come and gone at both senior and junior levels. My manager has changed several times and so have their managers and so on.
- Difficult promotion process that relies on juniors really needing to get to know a handful of seniors who might ordinarily be too busy or too new to understand what's going on.
- No mentoring or professional development plan. Appraisal system has had empty objectives for the past few years.
- Technology 5-10 years behind but the managers don't know it and are reluctant to change.
- Very heavy management hierarchy with reporting lines spread across the globe and poor communication and relationships from top down.

review_title: Great deal experience, but a large firm to navigate
pros:
- Great deal experience across M&A, lev fin, ECM, etc.
- Good company with a strong global brand
- a lot of internal and external recruiting options
- prestigious brand will create exit-opportunities, especially into buy side
cons:
- Large firm with a lot of people in each group makes it feel very "corporate" at times and less "entrepreneurial"
- Progression is often a fixed time thing and not always based on merit
- Given the size of the firm, there are still many weak links in senior roles across groups, however, most of senior roles filled with strong people
- Very, very, very tough for work/life balance; firm trying to implement policies to improve this (1 weekend off a month for example), but it is what it is
- Lower pay than other investment banks 
- Revolving door mentality, especially as a junior employee, you are there for a period of time to work, then you'll likely leave the company (very little internal progression at junior level)

review_title: Good reputation and company, good to start your career there
pros:
- Many interesting people to work with
- Good place to start your career
- Interesting to see and learn how one of the best investment banks work
- Reasonable benefits
- Looks great on your CV
cons:
- Tech and processes are very slow and outdated in most parts (although way ahead of other banks)
- Way too much red tape around processes that could be easily automated. Your performance suffer because of that
- Very slow adoption to new technologies (always behind)
- Pay is lower than market average
- Very slow in releasing and planning products
- Too many unnecessary meetings and delegations between teams (could be drastically simplified)

Advice to potential candidates (tech savvy people who want to learn/grow): its a good starting place and great opportunity to see that beast from inside, but I won't recommend staying for too long as you can start to become a tech dinosaur (market moves x100 faster than processes there).

pros: Secured work environment, Good Transport facility, Good Work Life balance, Internal movement opportunities, opportunities for extra curricular activities
cons:
It seems doing your BAU right without any escalation doesn't have much value. The Value is added always by in what extra curriculum activities did you participate?

You might feel disappointed when you observe your colleague with same year pass out but in technology with an associate and you at Senior Analyst or Analyst.  I came to know in some tech departments they hire people with less experience also at Associate level.  In technology, I came to know that appraisal is not based on what extra curricular activities was performed. It is purely performed based on your performance

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Canton, OH
pros:
Great benefits offered even at part-time.
As long as you follow policies the job is fairly easy.
cons: Had way higher expectations for this company! Management is fickle and unless you are a favorite don't look to get promoted here or be accommodated even when it comes to scheduling. The phrase "It's who you know." is true within this company.  Witnessing potential qualified candidates get overlooked all because management had their own personal reasons as to why they would not promote them.  Very hostile and unprofessional work environment. I just expected way more for such a high end, for profit business. Too many inconsistencies between branches and management. Picking and choosing what to follow and enforce which makes it very difficult to know what is allowed. No constructive feedback but you will be insulted indirectly and possibly reprimanded. Wish I would have escalated concerns higher up but it wouldn't have made much of a difference because work buddies get passes.

review_title: Best of the Banks - but tread with caution into financial services in this environment
pros: If you are in financial services, JPMorgan is the place to be. The executive leadership is phenomenal, and the bank well positioned to come out of the current crisis in great shape. From a technology perspective, a lot of time and effort is spent running it as a business, but also focusing on being a fast follower of leading edge capabilities. Huge budgets, and the ability to do things that would be far too expensive elsewhere.
cons: In the current environment, there is a sort of stigma being associated with a bank - especially one that is now partly owned and "managed" by Washington. However, JPM has good things going for it. Not enough real innovation and a lot of waste in duplicative systems and processes - part of the downside of being sugh a huge organization.

pros: Overall benefits are good except for last years change in medical benefits. There is a career path for advancement however time frames are unrealistic.
cons: Senior management and head of operations refuse to accept responsibility for the dysfunctional operations groups. Too many legacy systems and red tape to complete simple tasks. There is a lot of pushback from back office operations and service delivery times are too long and do not live up to private bank standards. This is not a service-only role. You will be required to do sales. Morale was at very low levels when I left.

pros: I'm sure there could be pros, but not working in a dysfunctional unit where everyone was quitting because of horrible, unorganized managers.  Hopefully in other groups or areas, it runs better.
cons:
1)  Working for someone who had no reason, training, or knowledge of being a team lead.
2)  having nothing to do for months on end because your manager didn't know how to delegate work because she's used to doing it all herself.
3) Not making sure your open req was going to be an actual position before hiring someone

pros: There definitely is a lot of room to grow and succeed in this company as long as you make it known to your manager. The branch I worked in was always fun to go to everyday, and our customers were delightful for the most part. I really liked how Chase did not force tellers to sell, and the fact that they gave us benefits puts them over the top. Hours were fine, and so long your management is friendly, there really isn't much to complain about.
cons: I probably would have not left Chase if I wasn't so stressed everyday. After they introduced the "no cash deposit" policy, collective employee morale sank. I was yelled and harassed by customers who did not bank with Chase and I had a few people submit complaints about me. Other than that, our customer base tended to be a bit snobbish. However, that's not really Chase's problem. It's the parents that raised these entitled jerks.

review_title: Great if you have friends in high places
pros: The money can be great. Overtime too, if you are part of the "chosen ones". Good meals in the cantine. The initial integration was really good, help for relocating, help to find accommodation, culture workshops.
cons:
It soon becomes apparent that if you are not French, or french speaking, then you are not part of the inner cirlce. Staff behave as if there are no rules for treating others with respect, so they don't bother. Most were just devious and furtive with their behaviour. Passive agressive behaviour was the norm. It was also normal for the French to talk and laugh about me whilst standing/sitting in close range.
The end for me came when so called colleagues (including management) tried to frame me for various things. It was really only thanks to one helpful union representative that I was able to stop this. (Another French union representative would never agree to meet or discuss anything with me, he was just too busy).
I took redundancy, and, I consider myself very, very lucky to have got out of this place.

review_title: Great place to work if you are lucky enough to work for a good manager
pros: Generally the benefits packages are pretty good, training and development is very much freely available. Mobility is pretty good, in the sense of moving within your own country and overseas.
cons: Promotions are incredibly difficult and are not compensated for. E.g you will more than likely stay on the same salary as your previous grade for at least another year/pay review season. Despite JPM having a solid vision and values, they are rarely demonstrated by senior management.

review_title: Good if you are from service company background
pros:
1. Competitive package
2. Year end bonus based on performance
3. Decent work-life balance
4. Lot of different teams with options for mobility among them (after min. 2years)
cons:
1. Being a large company, there is lot of beuracracy. Could be a turn-off if you are coming from start-up or product company cultures.
2. All the shots are called from global locations like US, UK or HK. In India it is more like a service company culture. Your inputs are not valued. Just do as they want it...
3. Minimal to zero documentation. there is no practice of documentation in IBs !  Most of the tasks are business driven and very dynamic. Again if you are from product company culture, then it is a major culture change.
4. Slow in adopting latest technologies.

pros: I am proud to have been an employee of this company. Once you become an employee, their benefits are top-notch and not only that, they have a ton of tools you can use to further your career. They're  also a company who really cares about the communities they serve--charities, row boat racing, Runs for Cancer...at great. I am sad I had to leave.
cons: The recruiters  are infamous for treating interviewing candidates as if they are numbers on the page – – they may help connect you with someone so you can interview, but if you were turned down for the role, you receive no communication on why you were turned down and any future emails are completely ignored.

review_title: Its a challenging but supportive and satisfying environment
pros:
JPMC is a thought leader in the market and both from experience and from comparing notes with others in the industry feels like one of the most dynamic and proactive organisations. Things can and will change quickly, surprisingly quickly, for such a large organisation it can adapt in a frighteningly short time.
Its pragmatic and well run - there is very little dogmatism - but a lot of practical common sense. I've seen some really fantastic things get done well ahead of competitors.
cons:
It is, or has become, beaurocratic, partly due to intense pressure from regulators and governments. I can only guess in common with the rest of the financial services industry there is a lot of process, and a lot of rules to follow/
It is huge and like any similar sized organisation can feel impersonal unless you have both the motivation and opportunity to forge relationships with people across the organisation.

review_title: We appreciate you so much that with the billions of net profits we earned last year, we're gonna decrease your incentive
pros: 3 Weeks PAID vacation + 3 personal days, a floating holiday, and sick time. Steady, reliable income.
cons: The company is restrictive in it's growth from within. They will hire outside talent before they promote those who are already skilled, and competent enough to make the cut. The chain of command is poorly managed. They say that the Employee Experience is a top priority but they don't back it up.

review_title: Used to be a good department
pros: Benefits there are no other pros
cons: Lied to often (told you can have chances to look at other departments or move around, which is not true), no consistency in leadership, constant change, constant movement of desks and supervisors, hr is no help if you bring up a concern, promotions for people who constantly say "they don't know" when you ask basic questions, leadership asks workers for advice on policy when they should know the answer, the harder you work and try the worse your treated, broken metrics system, and poor systems that are old and work part of the time. Poor morale.

pros: Good amenities and matching 401k.
cons: management  is the Peter principle to a tee. My manager had my office, and the other 10- offices in his region on a daily conf. call that lasted over 2 hours, (10 mins for my office, and then another hour 50 to listen to the other offices talk to him.) As a manager, you can't let poor employees go. HR is so afraid of a lawsuit, they "coach" employees who could care less about improvement non stop. These employees know the HR manual to a T, and they use everything they can get out of the company. Chase has no control over it's environment.

review_title: Good company overall, but not for software developers
pros: Pay and benefits are really good compared to other companies in London, and the work/life balance is good. In general I found colleagues and managers to be helpful and collaborative.
cons:
I'd suggest to avoid the company if you want to grow as software developers. The tools provided are not suitable to develop effectively (underpowered Windows laptop with no admin access, and plenty of spy/management software to slow down performances to an unbearable level); and in general, lots of legacy processes slow down productivity.
Promotion process is heavily dependent on managers/area and general company performance. Interestingly enough, the individual performance plays a minor role, so you can have individuals rated at the maximum level for years in a row that never get promoted; that is particularly true for promotions to higher levels (executive/MD).

review_title: Summer Technology Analyst Program - Project Management
pros: The experience was great. I was placed on a Project Management team. The managers and team members were really helpful and were willing to teach me and answer any questions I had. We had weekly speaker series from local executives and remote speaker series from top management like the CEO, CIO, CFO, etc. These were very helpful and gave insight to how to get be successful at your job.
cons: It felt as though we were already working for JPMorgan. It wasn't much of an internship where you are interviewing the company to see if you want to work there. Compared to internships at other companies where the company takes you out to fun events, gives you company swag, has social events, JPMC was lacking.

pros: Benefits from day 1, 3 weeks vacation after 2 years, Employer paid Pension Plan- you're vested after 5 Years, they match 401K up to 5%.
cons: They don't do very good pay raises. When I started 18 years ago, the pay raises were 5%, you would think they would increase. Nope, they decreased down to 2%, and if you don't do well, they will take away from the 2% and give it to another employee.  In order to move around in the company, it seems to be that you have to know someone who will put in the good word for you to move on to another position.

review_title: Not the company it once was

job_title: Senior Project Manager in London, England
