pros: Great company for career growth and opportunities across various lines of business in banking, investments and asset management.  Stability can be found as regardless of the economy, their senior leadership finds ways to grow and increase profitability.
cons: It is a mega corporation, so bureaucracy and red tape stifle innovation of process.  Leadership is always in a state of flux as Jamie Dimon prefers his executives to have broad experience across lines of business. It makes sense in theory, however, those looking for stability in their management should look elsewhere.  I had 10 bosses in 8.5 years across four positions.

pros: Great brand and most people at the bank are kind and hard working
cons: Provide continuing education to bankers so they can uncover more investment opportunities in the branches. This is a sales job and unfortunately the sales training provided is pretty much non existent on the advisors and bankers.

pros: A lot of cutting edge technology, smart people and good pay
cons:
Brutal management in NY, sweat shop mentality.  Highly political.  Managers are forced to push a certain percentage (pre-determined) of their employees into needs improvement, meets expectations etc at review time.   This makes no sense because it forces them to put good people into needs improvement in order to meet the breakdown.
Also the place is political as hell.  "Visibility" is a huge thing.  The place is crawling with ambitious cutthroats who will stab you in the back while smiling at you in meetings.  Avoid it if you can

pros: The people I worked with (from analyst to Vice President) were great.  I learned a lot through working with others and because I was given significant responsibilities.
cons: The company as a whole does not care about the employees.  It is very clear that you are a number, even senior managers seemed to have no idea of the downstream impact of directives they sent down.  Despite having a strong management team, they had no power to affect the work life balance (which was aweful).  Also the resources dedicated to technology enhancements to improve efficiencies were laughable compared to what one would expect from such a major company.

review_title: Huge on Corporate Politics - and no concern whatsoever for the truth.
pros: Compensation, networking, paid certification to become a licensed banker
cons: Management will praise you one second and throw you under the bus the next. They tend to play the race card a lot - not always in your favor. No concern for investigating or discovering the truth. The longer someone has been there the more they can get away with. So it's really about whether or not you know how to scam the system.

pros: JP Morgan has a solid foundation.  They've been able to keep a realistic perspective of the overall economy and ever changing needs for their consumers.  They manage Risk and Controls with the highest standards, as this ensures their customers will be securely managed.  There's a reason they are still number one in the Banking Industry.
cons: Long term employees may need to move into other roles more frequently or outside of the firm, in order to manage up their own personal salary goals and/or careers; which can be disappointing, especially if they like their current work environment.  I'm sure this is the case for all large corporations.

pros: The company really does support you when it comes to providing you with the tools to learn. I had various mentors and services (pluralsight) at my disposal. I was also exposed to real world projects and actually had my application go live into producation
cons: The company is very fast paced and had a bit of false advertisment in their program. What i mean is that they brand themselves as a tech company, but in reality the company is a bank and is focused on the financial side not the tech side which i understand. Also the TAP program is advertised as rotational , but it really isn't from what i hear with the full time TAP employees.

pros:
Good place to work - has a feel good factor about it.
Been here 3 years and so far so good.
Systems WORK. Since day one - all my systems have worked - without a hitch. 
Things just seem to work on the IT side.
cons:
It is BIG.
JPM has tried to outsource most operations to India / Philippine Islands and doesn't always seem to work.
HR policies on annual performance change all the time - there was the aspect of "forced ranking" which meant x percent had to be marked down whatever they do all year - I got into that category for two years. 
Moving internally seems to be very challenging - my mentor told me straight he would rather recruit external than bother training internally by looking internally....

pros: Opportunity to innovate and embed new ideas. Collaborating culture when your inside the house.
cons: Jamie a man of honest direct feedback but management in Asia seem to lack  honesty and integrity unlike other organisations. People treat you as an outsider once you’re out. If you wish to return huge abuse of power, bias and politics come into play. The very same people are not willing to tell you to your face as they hide behind the co!! Sad as they ruin the brand of a great company...

pros: Chase is an interesting place to work because you can collaborate with all levels of employees in locations all over the US (or even globally).
cons: Despite the fabulous press, there is much cost cutting (and job cutting) going on.  Employees have to bring their own toilet paper, paper towels, water and coffee in certain locations.  Some employees describe their work teams as "the island of lost toys" because of the mixed results of mergers and downsizings.  Promotions are simply out of concept.

pros: Peers can be fantastic to work with.  Locations are easy to get to via public transportation.  Big company means lots of different places to work.
cons: Low pay for experience.  Senior management does not care how hard you work or how much personal time you give up for the company.  They talk about caring for their employees and how their employees are their greatest asset, but they don't walk the talk.  All that matters is meeting arbitrary quotas for projects, timelines, and staffing.

review_title: WM operations, Nothing new to learn
pros: World class company, US Management is very inspiring and people friendly
cons:
Specially for Wealth Management operations, the higher management has attitude like Indian bureaucrats. The TL and below population is treated as if they are mere peasants and management is royalty. The vision and mission of Indian management is not at all aligned with the company's vision, the management is only interested in cost saving measures to impress their bosses
No clear path for career progression. Even if you bosses thinks that you are ready for promotion, their "governance" is that some random VP you have never met in your life will decide if you are ready or not.

Join only if you love to monotonous work everyday and no aspirations in life to learn or grow.

review_title: Chase mortgage underwriting for the birds
pros: Too frustrated with chase to find pros at this point.
cons: Chase seems to love to run lean.  Understaffing is a running trend,  they've run "mandatory OT" and productivity expectations that pretty much force you into 50 hour + workweek for not just the summer season, but season after season, year after year. Good money but in the end it will wear you down, and the compensation really isn't enough for this sacrifice in work/life balance. I've worked for other banks in the same or similar role and a high pressure for for ever increasing productivity while the processes and systems become ever more complex and the support staff ever more scarce is a common theme in mortgage, but chase takes it to far.  The stress is really high and a job that requires a good mind but at it;s core is not too complicated is really made a nightmare headache here.  Theres other lenders out there that treat their employees better, look elsewhere first.

pros:
Open working culture where questions and new ways of working are encouraged
Management were supportive of development opportunities
Colleagues were mostly helpful and supportive
cons:
It can be difficult to progress work across departments as it is such a large & complex organisation
Some staff seem to be there for the compensation and are that not interested in the work
Management structures across the business i.e. operations & product can make it difficult for teams to work together, and differing priorities can make it hard to work towards the same company goals

pros: Good quality work. Very technical company at par with any hitech IT company. Good bonus, nice hike. Vendor trainings given you get approval from project. Cab facility is awesome. Work life balance depends on project but usually not bad (work pressure is obviously there). Wfh setup is robust but not a culture and limited.
cons: Politics. Manager favouritism. Need ready made resources which deliver results quickly not wasting time in thinking putting pressure. Will contain you to the skills you are hired for. Won't approve trainings if not relevant to project ignoring career aspirations.

pros: In my opinion the strongest reason for JPMorgan Chase are the easy and fun down-to-earth colleagues and I had the impression that my team wanted me to learn and develop my skills even though I was just there for an interview. The culture seemed very open and relaxed, the work-atmosphere always was enjoyable.
cons: I cannot give real downsides except for the normal contra-banking arguments like long hours. IT was often slow and backoffice functions required chasing, which is both also normal at investment banks.

pros: Good benefits. A lot of career opportunities. Once in the company, there are many different sectors in the bank you can get promoted to.
cons: There is currently a hiring freeze in the company. Tons of people are getting let off. I've been with the company for almost 7 years and they are not willing to promote me as a banker. Even with a college degree in economics, they will not budge. All the managers tell you they are willing to help you in any way, but when it comes down to it, they don't help with much when you ask for their help. They are plenty of incentives as a teller/banker, but they have cut down the percentages tremendously compared to 1-2 years ago.

pros:
JP Morgan Chase offers an excellent opportunity to improve your skills and move around in the organisation. The opportunities for training and upskilling and unlimited and so is the opportunities for getting a mentor and get invaluable growth support.
The Organisation works and uses almost all of new technology tools and has an excellent and solid technology footprint.
A new focus on the leadership development is another great example of the company's focus.
cons:
Of late, there is lot of senior leadership changes and re-org of the departments, which at times make people annoyed.
Sometimes the workload becomes extremely heavy too.

pros:
Like-minded and youthful team atmosphere (within the 2-5 yrs work-ex age bracket)
Friday fun including team dinners and team bonding actiivites (though entirely dependent on the "people pillar" spocs)
cons:
Low start salary (and subsequent low increments in actual INR terms - even though you may have been awarded a >30% hike :D)
Mis-matched nodal pickup timings for the L&T Biz Park office - especially painful when you ended up logging in 50 mins before actual shift timings and more often then not had to "stretch" beyond 9 hours to complete tasks

pros: Great pay and bonus for starting analysts right after college. Strong company that truly best-in-class professionalism. Exciting work with community heavy-weights. Great brand that competitors recognize. Many benefits and perks. Great team environment.  You really feel like you're at the top of finance.
cons: Overly-conservative. People will judge you on everything and individualism is not encouraged at all. You are at the mercy of the bank when it comes to location and work-life balance (although much more flexibility is given at commercial bank). You are expected to know your stuff when you come through the door. Little support is given to help you if you're not.

pros: I have 35+ years as Commerical Banking...and also Customer Services as a City letter. Carrier for 9 years...my personality plus experience will be a great additon to your company...I so very interested in becoming employed by JP MORGAN....THK U ...248-692-3425....LEUTTICIAH LIGON.....ready to work A.S.A.PM
cons: Sometimes working with the public and money is adown fall....but to put your experience and itelkigent together will get you up hill....there's always down falls...but getting the job done is the factor

review_title: They talk it, but they don’t walk it.
pros: It’s a major corporation, with worldwide name recognition.
cons: Racism and discrimination among the branch staff and management in suburbia runs amok.  This includes but is not limited to racist jokes made by staff about clients.  If you are seen as being isolated you are at the mercy of branch partners that may openly express their desire to not with you, and  then not credit you appropriately with sales simply because you are seen by them as being “different”.  If, by chance you are unlucky enough to hear coworkers using actual racial slurs and dare report it to management and HR you will face severe retaliation.

review_title: Great company, great opportunity, great leadership
pros: The ability to advance and grow with the company. The leadership of the company is very key also. Jamie Dimon is doing a great job to keep the JPMC above the rest. There has not been many job cuts or disastrous news, which is great since we are in an economy that is very sensitive right now.
cons: There is much to learn when you first start. Not everything is laid out for you and sometimes  you have to take the initiative and go out to find your own answers It maybe overwhelming at time.

review_title: Great company overall.  Too big for employee focus
pros: Great place to work if you have a great leader in place.  Coincidentally the top branches in the nation have great leaders organizing, guiding, and coaching to make sure employees soar in their careers.
cons: Bad to place to work if your leader sucks.  Do I have to say more...Unfortunately, the company is so big and positions are demanding.  They just fill the position with some knucklehead who somehow  did great in something but have no idea how to lead a group.

pros: I joined JP Morgan as a Software Engineer a while back, and really enjoyed my time there.  Amongst the programming team I was a part of, everybody supported each other and wanted each other to succeed.  There are some tremendously knowledgeable people there including several "big names" in the software development field.  Management are generally very smart and seem to be all ex-tech.  Meetings are always short.
cons: Fairly long hours, though this seems to be at least partly voluntary.  Bizarrely for such a wealthy company, hard-drive space on PCs is very limited, causing some people to waste a bunch of time deleting unneeded files from time to time(!). Mandatory "training courses" which had absolutely no applicability to anything I was or ever would be doing.

review_title: Good place to start for Finance graduates
job_title: Transaction Processing Specialist/Financial Market Products in Mumbai
pros:
1. Sodexo coupons
2. Global exposure
3. Bonus & perks
4. Amazing facilities provided apart from sodexo and bonus
cons:
1. Concept of free speech and opinions dwindles with time
2. Your peers in another investment firm will rake in more in terms of basic salary
3. Redundant systems
4. No efforts to make the processes paper-less

pros: I have worked for J.P Morgan Chase Warsaw Corporate Center more than 1 year. Good brand name, learning opportunities are only pros.
cons:
Where to begin;
 
1-  Preferential treatment: Selective group of people controls who gets which task. They assign tasks not based on merit but personal relationships. That is ofc calculated move to promote individuals that are close to managers.

2- Equal is a buzz word 

3- Actual tasks: Not for people with ambition, there are people whom I know just have 5 mins daily tasks nothing more.

4- Networking "Done in a wrong way": When I say networking, I mean gossiping VPs, exploring others' vulnerabilities, any material that can be used to make one suffer should there be a need.

5 - Office Politics

6- Inclusion & Official Language: The official office language of JPMC isn't ENGLISH.  If you don't speak Polish then you are likely to be excluded from conversations, decision making etc.

8- Bait and switch is real: You may not be getting the job you have applied for.

review_title: Executive Assistant - Mortgage Vice Presidents - secondary market
pros: Best reason to work at JP Morgan Chase was they are a solid company large company we had excellent benefits.  I was a rehire with the company, so I knew the company when I went back to work there. I worked in secondary mortgage managers, assistant vice president and president with monthly and quarterly meetings, reports, & traveling expenses among other things.
cons: Continue to develop employees, criss train them inter departmentally and offer opportunities to those looking to move the ladder.

pros: The company provides competitive pay for its full time positions within the standard hours of operation. For its temps and interns, it acts as a fairly good model for entry level jobs into the world of big business office settings.
cons: Like many big businesses in the NY metropolitan area, especially in the banking industry, employees are often viewed as expendable. Because of that mentality, boundaries are frequently over stepped by management regarding the expectation of their employees to constantly work extra hours without reasonable compensation.

pros: Depends on your direct manager. They feed you almost every day, so that is a benefit aside from the pay.
cons: Again, depends on your direct report. Upper management sits in their cubicles pulling reports all day or having meetings. Your direct report - if they like - can get you promoted regardless of your efficiency or production in your job. If your direct report does not like you, they will harass you to the point they get you fired - regardless of how well you do your job. I have seen this. Upper management is not concerned with this, they just plug in another part.

pros: Good company. Good brand name but worst managers and seniors.
cons:
No team culture, people will do their best to hide what they know about the project. No sharing of info regarding the project, if you ask they will complain to managers that you are not good.

They expect that you are a super man and know everything about project  and do assigned work without any background given to you. If you ask doubts then you are gone.

No work life balance.

Will extract your life out.

Seniors will gang up against new comers and treated badly.

Politics, Politics, Politics good people will be made to quit

pros: You can get the best salary in industry if you can negotiate. Has a great reputation of its brand. You will get annual bonus if you complete one year in company from 1st Jan to 31st Dec. Also performance bonus is there. Has flexible working hours. You will get 20 paid leaves and 10 sick leaves every year which is not carry forward able.
cons: In pay structure basic component is quite low resulting in higher tax deduction and less epf. Office space is not up to the mark in quality. You will not get a second chance if you do any mistakes specially if it impacts production.

pros:
If you get a good branch it is really nice
Some will work with school schedule 
Most weekends off (usually managers will have you work every other, on a fair rotation for everyone) 
Decent benefits, Medical/Dental/Vision for all employees (Partime through Fulltime)
cons:
Keep cutting bonuses 
Tellers no longer get an end of year bonus 
Keep cutting staff at branches (not firing, just won't replace once someone leaves) which you then acquire the workload with no pay raise 
Every branch is in a competition with themselves and then based on how you end the year you may not even get a raise if the other branches did better, or that means your raise will be $.10-$0.25 maybe, and bankers never get raises.

pros:
Good pay masters
Great facilities
Good Brand name
cons:
Not many mobility opportunities to learn as there is a lot of bureaucracy to move to a place that is not your domain if you express interest in learning.
Promotions - you need to have a high rating for consistent 3 years to get promoted (only in India), if you have a meet expectation on year 3 you are at the back of the queue for another 2-3 years while an employee from another org can be pulled into that position with way less exerience

pros: Nice environment, great pay, awesome people to work with, faced-paced environment, pantry concessionaires are the best!
cons: Doesn't really give people second chances after 6 months of probationary period. I was, at that time, from a tech and sales company where it doesn't matter if we spent 45mins to an hour over the phone. I wasn't given any warning beforehand that after 6 months of not performing what they expect you to be, they'd kick you out. My manager, was on maternity leave, so the relief manager was there; she didn't even defended me. I had to look for another job in like, a few days before Christmas. It was a hard time for me since I am the breadwinner of my family, it's even harder to let them know that I lost my job. Any heads-up from the very beginning would've been appreciated.

review_title: Great brand and place to work
pros:
Brand value - top financial services company in the Fortune 500 list
Awesome place to work - great facilities
Overall a good talented bunch of people 
Ample internal job opportunities thru mobility
cons:
Usual slowness in process that comes with the size of the company
Salaries used to be at top in industry earlier, but not now. There are other companies that pay more than JPMorgan now.

job_title: Mortgage Underwriter in Downers Grove, IL
pros: Good benefits, vacation policy is 3 weeks to start.
cons:
Raises are almost non-existent, salary lower than similar companies; most people have to leave and come back to get a competitive salary.  Policy is you have to be in current position 2-5 years before they would consider advancement (regardless of abilities and knowledge) and even then, there might be no pay increase if you are advanced.  
Training is poor and ongoing training is limited to compliance issues and guideline updates only, nothing skill improving. They have very high standards, but do nothing to help you achieve those standards.

pros: Four weeks of vacation. Opportunities to work with new technologies if you get involved with the right people. Flexible working hours and arrangements for work-life balance.
cons:
Poor communication from your manager where many times you will not get a response. Beware of review time and do not let your manager talk you into marking off you have reviewed your performance plan at mid year. Keep them on track and have them work with you on your development and performance plans.  Long hours and many times, you cannot take compensation time off. Hopefully, you can use up your vacation.
They frown upon reimbursing college expenses and will ignore you when you submit the paperwork.

review_title: Good climate, but the functions are so standarized.
pros: Good benefits (over the market). Work-life balance is ok. Also, you can find a lot of different people in the organization and you have the real chance to connect with a lot people around the world (at least by email and telephone).
cons: The functions are so standarized and the profile for each position as well. Maybe is a problem related to the country more than the organization, but you can realise that all people is so stereotype for each position, that's why I decided to quit the job. When I had my round last interview, with my boss, he told me sincerely that to apply for a position as investment analyst you needed to be part of "the country economic elite".

review_title: Good place to work...if you live near a hub location
pros:
JPMorgan is a prestigious and successful company.  There is a vast opportunity for employment, depending on geographic location.

Pay is competitive and mostly fair.

JPMorgan provides a good benefits package including a 401K, retirement plan, and other benefits and services.
cons:
JPMorgan is currently in a resource consolidation cycle.  There is a very real danger of job elimination or relocation, especially for remote employees.

Promotion is often driven more by politics than performance.

The cost of healthcare coverage has rapidly increased in the last 5 years.  Their health plan now follows a co-insurance model.

Managing risk has become a major priority for JPMorgan.  Administrative tasks have increased exponentially in the past 5 years.

review_title: Overall very good, but there are pockets of frustration
pros: JPMorgan pays well and provides good benefits. It has a stellar reputation in the market and has solid senior management. Provides solid opportunities for mobility due to its size. The commitment to mobility is also solid. Excellent support with immigration issues.
cons: There are parts of the company where the culture of fostering work-life balance does not trickle down. Management can be frustratingly slow at dealing with dealing with a toxic and hostile work environment as long as revenue numbers are being met. Performance evaluations can be very political and driven by likes and dislikes and can be driven by people who have poor understanding of what is needed to get the job done.

review_title: Private Bank Client Service associate is a great role to get an extremely well rounded and in depth learning experience.
pros: The role has a lot of exposure to many areas of the bank which gives you the opportunity to choose from a variety of career paths. You have the opportunity to work with many high net worth clients for all of their needs.
cons: It is a very high pace and in depth role that has a bit of a learning curve. This role is the perfect position to transition into being a private banker. We have the expertise and knowledge in all areas. There seems to be a disconnect in this aspect as many employees who choose to go that route make lateral movements and then have to work up to the private banker level.

pros: Excellent technology based company, following good agile maturity process.
cons:
No job security
No flexibility
No work life balance 
Completely demotivated environment because of uncertainties. Managers and skip level dint really have any capabilities to handle/call out such uncertainties and motivate the team.
They say its a transparent environment but If you call out any concerns you will be in the list for sure
People manager plays safe games and politics because of their insecurities.
We dont know who is our HR and they won't even interact with people
No proper vision for the product development.
Note: Only our lob is like this, rest of the comp. is fine

review_title: WaMu was great while it was Wamu!
pros: It was a great company that cared equally about its employees and customers.  There was very little hierarchical levels as the company was very straight lined.  A manager could provide feedback to the executive management with ease and the company blog allowed employees to speak freely about the company and how to improve it.
cons: Now that it has been acquired by JP Morgan Chase, we can already see the cultural differences affecting our work environment.  So far, it appears Chase does not treat its employees with the same fairness and respect as WaMu did.

review_title: Awesome opportunity if you are willing to put meaningful time in.
pros: Great opportunity if you really ask for it and work hard.  You can move up quick and be recognized.  Reasonably competitive pay, great bonuses again if you put an amazing amount of hours in.  Reasonably good access to training internal and external.  Internal access to tools and technology have great improved the past three years.  Good retirement, employer match to 401k, great dental and vision.
cons: Not of a lot of great technology managers with vision, those that do are awesome.  Health Benefits are horrible.  High senior management turnover, there are glass ceilings that you just can't break unless you know someone.

review_title: Very large organization, can sometimes feel like a number.
pros: Leadership is focused - CEO sets strategy for the organization and the leadership will be focused on executing his strategy.  Office culture is collaborative.  Most individuals are helpful and willing to help to ensure projects move forward.  Time off policies are average; as a VP, I got less vacation time at JP Morgan Chase than my previous company.
cons:
Can be very political.  Some individuals will not hesitate to throw people under the bus, so to speak, to forward their career.  But I suppose this is true for most organizations.
I worked there for almost 5 years.  The bonus program is generous and given annually.  Raises were not given annually - I guess the bonus makes up for the lack of raises.

pros: J.P. Morgan provides great exposure to the markets (stocks, bonds, alternatives) while giving you a foundation for sales and success.
cons: There isn't a clear cut promotion process as there is a huge gap in job requirements from the Analyst to the Associate/VP level.  There needs to be some form of fill the gap.

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: Friendly People, Events, Networking,  Learning, Very very few good senior leaders
cons: No work life balance, no equality in distribution of work, Low salary, ur ratings and bonus doesnt have any linkage..you can get the highest rating but the lowest bonus, depends on managers mood. People with lower rating gets higher hikes and people with higher ratings are not even given decent hike..totally bureaucratic..No fair review process, the stakeholders are not even involved sometimes, no record of the feedback on the tool from the stakeholders..

pros:
Training - Company provides  a wide range of class room trainings both on technical and soft skills. This is free and can be attended with manager's approval.
Free transport - Every 1.5 hours company buses shuttle in all major routes. After 8 p.m cabs are available for house drop. 
Salary and bonus - The pay is based on your role and previous pay but yearly  bonus is good.
Discipline- Company puts lot of focus on the security, work ethics and every employee is expected to take lot of mandatory trainings on do's and don'ts as well as abide by the rules like not exposing code to an external site, not to post details of work and photos on social media etc. Also there is no access to any social media or external mail accounts. This is restrictive but it's a bank and requires it.
Internal mobility- Every 2 years one can change the team if they wish to. This is the policy and your manager cannot stop you. But you have to clear the interview process and meet the expectations of the new team.
cons:
Day shift Timings -  If you are expecting 9-6 day shift this is not the right place to work. Almost all teams work from 11am to 8pm as the telecalls happen in the evenings. That's is the general expectation and if you prefer normal 9 to 6 you need to talk to your manager as it's a special case. If you have commitments in evening like picking child from school etc. this is not the right place to work.

Culture - Vendor mentality prevails in Bangalore teams. The projects are driven from US which is understandable as it's an American company. But your work life balance is also controlled by US team. You feel you are a contractor not an employee.

No work from home- Wfh is generally discouraged in Bangalore office.

Technology - Company is going through major revamp on technology front. There are lot of migration projects on UI migration, moving to cloud, adopting Big Data etc. There are teams that do great technical projects related to data mining and stuff but there are many teams that do merely support work that doesn't require much technical excellence.

Domain- Most of the projects are on backend applications whose usage is limited to a team in Operations group internal to the company. If you have worked in product companies where the applications are used by end customers this experience is rather confining.

review_title: Company is good, tech is bad
pros: Great treatment of employees, work life balance, and work events. They make sure their employees are entertained. People are generally nice.
cons: For a software engineer, the tech is dated (expected for a bank) and slow moving due to many manual processes, approvals, and dependence between teams. Don't expect anything cutting edge, and don't expect to be practicing many skills that are transferable. Lots of showboating for specific teams and a culture where talking the talk (buzzwords = praise) is valued over walking the walk. Developer tools are slow, buggy, and crash consistently. Lots of time waiting around for things to start functioning again.

review_title: Great people, great culture and management
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Tel Aviv-Yafo
pros:
- Great people to work with and to study from.

- A small hub, with a huge focus on technology.

- The thrive for innovation is every where, you want to invent something new? Sunday projects are very much appreciated.

- Great products with huge scale and true impact on global scale.

- Great local leadership, very focus on making the employee life better, on every aspect - from past time life balance, local amnesties and the will to listen to which ever we have to say, all is very transparent.
cons:
- Hertzeliya pituach is not the best location to work at, Access to public transportation is very limited.

- A huge corporation, American companies do love their bureaucracy and audit.

review_title: Company which needs a proper roadmap/vision in terms of tech.
pros:
- Flexible work arrangements
- Lot of trainings offered
- Salary and bonus structure are good.
cons:
- Not much learning since they use legacy code and tools.
- Management restructuring happens most of the time and hence the vision keeps on changing.
- No proper goals/roadmap for a project.
- No work-life balance as you are expected to support 24*7 even as a developer.
- Interviews are of moderate/tougher levels but nothing is applicable in real-time.
- Most of the work is support related and no proper development work takes place which makes people leave since developers are expected to enhance/built code and not be on calls with business most of the time.

pros: Obviously, everyone who works here is in it for the money.  That's clearly evident in day-to-day life at the firm, and if you think that there's some kind of corporate culture...wow, you might be stupid.
cons: Your superiors will be morons, and you will be forced to work long hours.  I've had the rug pulled out from under me time and time again, and eventually it's not even a surprise.  Working at JP Morgan is essentially being chained to your desk, albeit with golden handcuffs.

pros: There was a lot of career advancement opportunity at WAMU. The people were very nice and WAMU paid VERY well! I was given a lot of respect in the company and once you develop a good reputation with folks, then you are granted a lot of opportunities.
cons: I never liked their review process. We were given a rating between 1-5, but I know for certain that they started everyone at a 3 (which meant you would get the bonus).Unless you did an awful job, you'd get the bonus, so the review process seemed like a waste of time.

review_title: Company has prestige but also a lot of politics
pros: Great prestige, security of job and it provides the training you would expect from a top tier bank. The fact that it includes IB, Asset Management, PB, Custody etc gives a lot of room for changing
cons: The company is huge and politics exist. Especially regarding promotion and pay its stab or be back stabed. The environment is competitive and its hard to make friendships

pros: Opportunities seem to be forthcoming, but only to established locations.  A ton of resources here to help you grow as an employee, and plenty of training is available.
cons: Work from home is not generally offered, even if it makes sense to do so.  Even though this is a huge company with a lot of resources, getting a raise and/or promotion is extremely difficult.  Due to the size of the company, upper management does not know you exist, and the company culture is entirely dependant on who you are surrounded with.

pros: Great name recognition, well organized, plenty of resources and opportunities to gain exposure and knowledge about different areas in the bank
cons: In my particular area, senior bankers were too busy and did not have time to mentor and guide the interns.  Somehow it felt as if I was in a small firm not a bulge bracket bank.  However, I believe this was a unique case because interns in other areas felt they received adequate guidance and support.

review_title: Not much growth plus no flexibility
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Good salary, that's the only thing I can say as plus point, joining JP. But that too is not very much high. You can get it outside as well.
cons:
No flexibility at all was in my team. Make sure to clear it before joining with your hiring manager.
New building is in Docklands with no public transport going near to ofc. It's a long walk to reach office which is more difficult in rain. 
Third, check-in checkout everyday using a tool to monitor your hours.

In terms of growth, you will be dependent on US team's pity to provide good work. Everything is decided by team sitting in US, even how many leaves one can take altogether. Your local lead has no power usually to make any decisions for you. 
No social club. No discount coupons. Cafeteria food is good but expensive, and as this new building is on Docklands, you don't have much options as well nearby.

review_title: JPMorgan Investment Bank - Futures and Options
pros: Renumeration, job prospects and corporate name. Compensation is much better than my previous employers (US Software vendor) and bonuses are a perk. The opportunity to move about within the same company but to a massive number of different roles is also a great situation to be in. The general nature of managers and management is helpful, even in these hard times.
cons: In some technology areas, there are too many 'managers' - in name or actual job roles - but not enough individuals to do the work.

pros: Strength of the company, great leadership from CEO Jamie Dimon, promotions based on performance.  This company has the best overall technology and sales model in the industry.
cons: Overall compensation below competitors, no intelligent spending authority given to managers, very process driven.  (Reduces creativity and makes employees feel expendable.)  Current morale is below where it should be at a company this strong.  To truly move up in the company, you must be willing to relocate if not in NYC.  Overall upper-management does not manage the "people" part of the business very well.  (Very numbers driven with too much pressure on entry-level salespeople and not enough true career development.)  Good managers are self-taught at JPM.

review_title: Life at JP Morgan Chase & Co.
pros:
Very big company with lots of opportunities
Pretty good work environment
Flat hierarchy, which means you don't have too many levels (starts from Team Member to CEO, about 9 Levels)
Decent pay master
cons:
Does have a lot of opportunities, but at times they look for very weird combinations
If you are an MBA from the second rung B-Schools,expect yourself to be end up in MIS kind of roles. 
If you are a techie, ensure that you have a technical manager during the interview.
Not the best pay master, Morgan Stanley, Nomura, DBOI, etc. pay much better
One important thing, J.P.Morgan Chase & Co. is basically J.P. Morgan and Chase who are very different in their approach and have very different work environments as well. Chase is more open and friendlier than J.P.Morgan side.

review_title: Great company, smart & diverse set of people
pros: One of the best training programs on the street for investment banking.  Summer analyst class was filled by people from many different schools -- definitely a plus when you're trying to build a firm that needs to relate to clients from many different backgrounds as well.  You learn so much and connect with so many people over such a short time.
cons: Investment banking hours can be brutal.  You usually have to show up to the office around 9 o'clock and stay past midnight to work on projects/models.  Your workload is highly variable, but if you do have some downtime, your managers usually have no qualms about you stepping out for an hour to go to the gym and come back.

review_title: Great Company but tired of the layoffs
pros: Good environment, good chance to move up in the company, great health benefits, 401k, great amount of vacation time after a few years.
cons: About every 3 to five years they will have layoffs.  Even if you are doing great at your job you can never really feel secure.  If this does happen they do try and help you find another job in the company but it can take time.

review_title: Let's get bigger, bigger, bigger oh, and by the way, we're laying off 30% of the workforce.
pros: Global company; lots of opportunities for movement; decent benefits; work/life balance is dependent on who your manager is; good sense on teamwork to get the job done.
cons: Pay is significantly below market especially if you plan to stay with the company; every three years they take over another bank before they have their act together with the prior takeover; constant restructuring and layoffs while the big dogs take home huge bonuses.

pros: lots of perks and benefits, smart people, good hours, if you are a great fit you'll do well.
cons: lots of back stabbing, For management, if you're in the "club", you're in and if you're out, you're OUT!.  Bonus' and raises only for the chosen few and they make you know that you are not favored and should move on....promotions are very arbitrarily given not based on any criteria, just if you are favored or not(actually if you ride NJTransit with the boss and kiss his you get the idea)....keep away from the back office...its a dead end.

pros: Training was great, where they make it easy to learn the tools that would be used on the job. They offer great benefits on hire date. After training and 6 months of working the shift hired for they offered other shifts that could be requested for to fit personal lifestyle which was great. Not only did they provide the tools to make work efficient but they were constantly making improvements. If there was anything that was misunderstood team members, colleagues, and managers were always there to help.
cons: Challenges were small. The only challenge I ran into was that some other departments wouldn't be as informed or efficient so that a customer could be helped. That just opened up the opportunity to work a little harder to get the job done.

pros: The company provides significant paid vacation time, has on-site health care and many other perks for employees. The salary ranges are typically higher than similar jobs at other companies. Richer paid maternity leave policy and return to work support than other companies in my region. Surveys on employee wants, needs and general happiness were done annually and management tries to react to those results.
cons: Depending on the dynamics of the department in which you work, you could have a very positive or very negative experience. While this seems obvious, it is drastically different depending on the head of the department. Really take time to get to know the management in an interview and try to get perspective from peer employees to understand the true temperament of the department.

pros: Company is good. good brand name.
cons:
No team culture particularly in equities, people will do their best to hide what they know about the project. No sharing of info regarding the project, if you ask and persist, they will complain to managers that you are not good. Same people who complained to the higher management that I am not good came to me regarding advice how to crack Amazon interview. Poetic Justice.
No work life balance.
Will extract your life out.
Seniors will gang up against the freshers.
Freshers and new comers will be treated badly. If team is highly political,dont expect bonus and hike, 
Politics, Politics,  Politics good people will be made to  quit.

review_title: Push towards DevOps model is helping it pull ahead of competition
pros:
Push for DevOps, Agile model. 
Started using of Cloud-Foundry/AWS (though still only handful of applications in Production). 
Salary is competitive to other FinTechs.
cons:
Still ample bureaucracy to get even simple things done. Firewall port opening for example, takes 2 full weeks atleast in addition to chasing multiple teams for approvals. 
Like any large company, there are pockets of projects with good work vs bad work/culture. Its better to ask around before

pros:
Brand Name

Job Security

Looks good on Resume
cons:
Pay is not commensurate to experience level and work load

Bias behavior exist within both sides of the department US & UK; however more prevalent in UK as the UK counterparts are extremely bias and tends to pass on workload to the US team to keep from doing it.

UK Management are unhelpful (e.g. ignore emails) and if they do respond out of pity their response is of an snarky condescending tone.

No flexible work arrangement for US team but UK team have work from home options.

US Manager nepotism. 

No unity. 

Monotonous culture coupled with phony atmosphere.

Difficult to laterally move within another department that offers an substantial pay increase and title no matter the experience if you’re nonwhite.

pros: I was lucky to get matched on a great team with a good culture. Work/life balance was fine, lots of opportunity for learning, and a healthy atmosphere. Job security is rather safe. Really agree with the direction of senior management and their approach to organizing.
cons:
Wouldn't say everyone had the same experience. You could be matched in a bad role or a bad team and hate your life, and there's not much you can do except bite the bullet for a year and switch teams, hoping the grass is greener (it might not be).

You'll be better off going there, building your resume, and switching after 2-3 years to further your career if you want to be compensated fairly at market rate.

review_title: Great! Offers excellent training and ways to advance
pros: I have worked at Chase for 4 years and there are many pros. One is their extreme support of your long term goals, their ways to develop your career are great!
cons: In my past departments, the cons are professionalism. I used to work in a back office and they made it every difficult to voice your opinions or ideas. They hired whoever to their management team even if they were not qualified. This is not the case with my management team now, but I know this remains an issue in their back office

pros:
- The company invests well in developing employees' skills that are valuable in their performing their daily tasks such as conducting trainings in doing Macros in Excel, having online trainings on project management etc.
- Very diverse workplace
- Supports internal hiring and/or transitioning to different teams, lines of business, and even locations abroad
cons:
- Very slow computers
- Poor internal security as there were instances of theft within office premises
- Lack of work-life balance; depends on the team that you may be part of

pros: Amazing people who genuinely want to help you learn and become a professional. Very nurturing environment. As an intern, I was pleasantly surprised to get real responsibilities and exposure to what was going on in my field (as opposed to some friends who worked other places and did the typical intern grunt work).
cons: Really didn't have any downsides. The whole experience was good - insightful, enjoyable, etc. In a big company like JPM, it's very easy to feel lost. Employees and other interns made the company feel alot smaller and more close-knit.

pros: Smart people, sometimes a fun atmosphere depending on the group you worked for.  Plenty of people who have been in the industry for decades, mentors who are willing to help you learn.
cons: Mobility touted by management, but the problem is once you transfer to a different team - even though a higher salary would normally be justified by that new role, they almost always view it as a lateral move.  In other words, it's a resume builder for you, not an income/career builder.

job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Bournemouth, England
pros: Large global organisation who champions internal job opportunities over external people coming in. Plenty of opportunities to work for the company in different locations.  Had some fantastic big celebrity speakers which I was there. Whole office has been completely refurbished since I left so it's a nice working environment now so I've been told.
cons: Ridiculously over worked for the pay. Worked very, very long hours as management did nothing to increase headcount quickly enough to deal with fluctuations in volume. I changed Manager over 10 times whilst I was there which did nothing for my personal development so I had to establish a relationship with a new manager each time a performance review was done.

review_title: Invests in employees and improving satisfaction
pros:
- discounted travel
- dress down policy
- free wifi
- good work/life balance and flexible work arrangements
- internal mobility is encouraged
- continuous learning is heavily supported
- collaborative culture
- job security (easy to move to another team if team is made redundant)
cons:
- pay rise policies are not so friendly, easier to leave and return
- usual political crap one would expect in such a large org most especially with senior folk
- sometimes senior folk can get away with not doing much and taking some/all credit for the work of their subordinates

review_title: Work culture not very great...very aggressive onshore teams
pros: I have been working in JP Morgan since past 3 years...Pay, Transport and cafeteria is good.Teams are moving to the agile process. Good learning place for new technologies..
cons: Lot of Contractors/consultants absorbed as permanent employees onshore/on-site have created a monopoly and consider the offshore as second class employees. Offshore contribution on innovation is suppressed and taken away by the highly insecure onshore(Indian) employees. Raising this concern to management doesn't reach the rigth people and local talent starts quitting the organization. No Work life balance.

pros: Longevity. You tend to stay with the company for as long as you can stand it. Administrative roles are easy to get and most teams will ensure that your position is secure. The hours can be flexible which is a nice deal if that's important to you.
cons: The pay is not that great when you consider that this is one of the top financial institutions in the country. There is absolutely no room for growth because the environment is pretty stuck up. They only hire trust fund babies and Ivy Leaguers for positions outside the administrative realm. The company as a whole doesn't encourage diversity. Unless you intend to be a career assistant.

pros: The paid and benefits were good.
cons: You are only a number to management and HR.  They do not care how you grow within the company.  It does not matter your experience or skill or how long you work at the company.  If a new executive came on board, he or she can layoff or  offshore you without a blink of an eye.  They only care about how the stock is doing.  This is especially true working in Texas.

pros:
Good work life balance but depends upon team
Above average employee facilities like wfh, free transport, free cabs(home drop) post 8:00 PM
Good teammates also smart colleagues depending upon team
Appraisal are not that great if you are lateral hire for first year and even for others it may or may not be decent but bonuses are quite good 
Promotions are based on time/years spent not on talent
cons:
Work wise you may find it monotonous after spending few years.
Also learning graph does not increase after a year
Tax saving options are not that great
You have to book a seat everyday, no permanent desks are assigned and this is really a pain if you could not book a seat

review_title: Great entry role, use it to obtain licensing and move along
job_title: Licensed Relationship Banker- Small Business Specialist
pros: Work/Life Balance, Holidays and 3 weeks vacation starting
cons:
Very difficult to move from Branch Banking into another line of Business
Manager/Company keeps "you in a box" until they think you're ready for promotion (direct quote)
Little to no accountability from branch managers. They will not help with a difficult client and do not hold all employees to same standard. Lazy, pass the buck.

review_title: Opportunity to make money with a lot of OT I worked there for 5 years
pros: Decent benefits opportunity to make money by working a lot of overtime
cons: Too many training classes required  that have nothing to do with the job, Most of the time management doesn't know the job or have answers. You have to be a part of the good ole boys club to move. If you don't play into that club you can die at desk. Dirty work environment. Heard they were cleaning that up now all they need to do is clean up the management team.

review_title: Great people, but it comes at a price
pros: Great firm with lots of sales support, you can always get an answer if you have a question about ANYTHING. Great place to go and get your start as half the time you do not have to source your own client meetings. Good medical, health, dental, vision, retirement, and lots of time off.
cons: Management does not give a damn what happens as long as the money rolls in and the red tape everywhere. An extremely corporate climate that can get political quickly. The firm also pays bottom-dollar on commissions.

pros: Department as a whole had some great people. Activities and social away from the office helped keep a happy balance. Tough role but well rewarded if done right. Plenty of chances for progression and movement to different areas or countries.
cons: Standard office politics but with a slight ruthlessness to it. Everyone's part of the team but at the same time attempting to sell themselves as the star pupil to a manager fairly disconnected from the daily goings on. If something goes wrong it's a different ball game and you're on your own. Play the game or lose out at year end.

pros: JP Morgan is a great place to work if you are seeking advancement and challenge.  It is also a good place to learn about how the financial market works.
cons: If you are not already established then you may find it difficult to advance yourself professionally.  For example, it is best to finish your education because the company is not as receptive today as they were ten years ago to allowing employees to pursue a degree, especially if it is not in a field related to what you are presently doing.

pros: Great name, working for one of the best (if not the best) bank in the world. Compensation and benefits are average-pretty good.
cons: The analyst program that I'm in doesn't seem dedicated to helping their analysts succeed or move up within the company. The company is huge (250,000) so sometimes you do feel like just a number.

pros: Enormous company where you can know people from everywhere in the world. If you move fast, you can build a strong contact network. Technology is state of the art.
cons:
Very poor salaries. Uncertainty of working or not in Holidays (depending on job demand), bad management sometimes (managers are treated bad from their superiors so they do the same with their team).
Only once a year you get the chance to get promoted, so if you don't get picked you have to wait an entire year.
No benefits: no discounts, big bonuses.

review_title: JPMorgan Chase is a great place to work.
pros:
JPMorgan Chase is a well-known, prestigious company.

Part-time employees regularly scheduled to work just 20 hours or more each week are eligible for benefits.

Great work/life balance

Opportunity to earn bonuses based on company and individual performance

Employer-matching on charitable giving
cons:
Thinking really hard, I suppose a downside of working at JPMorgan Chase, or any other financial institution for that matter, is the heightened scrutiny and regulation that the government has on our employer.

With the company being as huge as it is, it is easy to be overlooked.

pros:
1. Arguably no.1 Investment Bank in US...has a large portfolio of work which India can support. This provides a potential for great learning and growth for employees
2. Has a brand image in India.
3. there is loads and loads of work
4. Great titles, Not too bad with Compensation Package too.
5. would be a good place for entry level positions to get exposure to the F&A domain. Potential to learn the subject at a very fast pace
cons:
1. Loads of reports and ops metrics gets generated. No one understands why they are asked to create so many reports. Good thing is that they are all manual (excel sheets and PPT's) and hence can always be 'tweaked' to tell a 'good' story
2. long working hours

pros: There are a lot of opportunities in this big company and room for growth if you play your cards right and if you belong on the correct side of the fence. It would really help if you are a local or if you know who you are working for because it would surely make your life easy. Lastly, putting this company name on your CV would really sound sweet.
cons: Too much bureaucracy. local management have less care for foreign workers who happens to work equally hard or even harder than local employees.

review_title: A Great Respect for the Brand
pros: Very proud of the brand, especially the community involvement aspect and our commitment to employ our veterans. Honoured to be an integral part of the organization to affect positive change and growth of frontline staff.
cons: Promotions based on cronyism rather than performance and what really matters. Managers often promoted in order to be moved out of their roles due to gross incompetence or excessive HR complaints instead of matching skill set, proven abilities and qualifications. Extremely difficult to post into other roles internally. Most internal recruiters are overwhelmed or unresponsive to needs of internal applicants.

pros: Good total compensation.  Working with highly intelligent and motivated people.  Technology is above most peers.  Mobility highly encouraged keeping employees engaged.  Flexible in the working hours allowing for work/life integration.
cons: Large company where roles and responsibilities across groups are not always clear.  It can sometimes be a struggle to get relatively simple tasks accomplished.  Important talent not always recognized for those that aren't great public speakers.

pros: Pay is excellent and generally above market (except at Associate level). With a few exceptions of course, excellent people, very smart and driven, and some very good managers. Outstanding in house education program. Generally meritocratic, although not without some politics. Inspiring CEO.
cons: Quite a few Executive Directors (just below Managing Directors) appear to have flat-lined and can make weak, troublesome managers who often generate unnecessary work. Evidence of true "mobility" limited, although it receives much lip service. Generally, it's investment banking, so it's not devoid of a culture of fear and stress.

pros:
Work-life balance
Transport facility
Year end bonuses
cons:
Biased managers who will screw/Play around  your career
Growth is very slow/People are stuck in one position for years/Till retirements  in some cases ,unless managers favors you , applicable only to India offices
Less to no Learning 
Manual Boring  work
Few old employees have made office their home, which they keeps on bullying others /new employees
Internal Job transfers are biased/Next to impossible unless you know the hiring managers personally  , equal to searching job outside firm 
No international exposure /Onsite
Slow long internal bureaucratic processes  
You would find difficult to find jobs in market post working hear as you will get outdated in your field of expertise

pros: The firm carries great brand name, which will give you advantage when you move to another job. Also, if you prefer working 24-7 than work-hard-play-hard, this is the perfect place for you. Meal compensation is better than other banks in Hong Kong. You can get exposed to various deals at early stage.
cons: Culture was a bit too boring and stiff. Given the location in Hong Kong, facetime exists. People always work hard, but there is not much socializing with your colleagues. Very dry culture. You are not really allowed to have casual interaction with your boss, which was also down-side. Watch your back.

review_title: A solid company with good benefits and good resources for helping your professional growth.
pros: It's a big company so there are many opportunities to try different roles and work in different areas. The benefits are good and they are big on giving you the resources to educate yourself through online courses in management and other skills.
cons: In many of the departments they work you hard with some long hours. On the retail side this is especially true. Also, it is hard to move from the retail bank side to a position at corporate.

pros:
They give you a book of business and it's your job to cultivate and build relationships.   Easy for proactive people to make a decent amount of money with a top performers trip.   Easy for reactive people to kick back and service people trying to cross-sell.   

Solid 401k, Employee stock plan, car discounts, hotel discounts, wellness plan, and etc.

Depending on your manager,  they are always willing to work with you on personal time and vacation workarounds.
cons:
-Health benefits are pedestrian
-Moving up in the company takes forever. (unless right time and place)
-Pay is weak.   Top bankers salaries are maxed at $65k base.  (Citigold starts at around $80k)

review_title: Great place to work, despite the red tape
pros:
- knowledgeable colleagues
- culture and diversity
- benefits and perks
- training and learning
- mobility opportunities
- investing in IT systems development
cons:
- lot of red tape; heavily regulated, internally and externally; too many meetings
- salary/bonus often below market rate
- job security/advancement
- too much reliance on offshoring in the last few years
- too many it legacy systems that do not communicate to each other

pros: The company is  extremely large with vast opportunities for those who seek them out.  For those that do not enjoy their job, there are many other opportunities to change careers or simply change teams.
cons: If you do not tend to be an extravert, you may get overlooked, but for those who shine you may wind up in the right place at the right time.  That's what it is all about right?

review_title: It's a shame that company such a JP Morgan hire such a people
job_title: Transaction Processing Specialist in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Salary and paid overtime
Some occasional work party if new business opportunity came
cons:
Overtime - working 10 hours a day  - You are expected to work until you have a work, doesn't matter what time it is, business never sleeps.
Your complains are never taken to consideration, you are just a number for them.
If you choose to have family or get engaged, you are out of game, not matter how hard you work, you can forget about your carreer growth.

review_title: Strong brand but low pay and limited opportunities
pros:
-The company brand is very strong and really does open doors to other companies
-Leadership is very strong and they are constantly in communication with everyone at the company
cons:
-Back office work is very boring
-Opportunities are limited at smaller offices
-There isn't really any preference given to employees applying for other roles/locations within the company
-Ambition to become the best manager in the investment world means there are many rules and regulations in place that often feel quite restrictive (average pay, limits on expenses, many restrictions on gifts, etc)

review_title: Very political place with more stability than most corporations nowadays.
pros:
Stability (relative)
Training (although some areas are very restrictive for college tuition reimbursement)
Lots of work available
There is no end to what you can learn about what the company is doing
cons:
Many managers expect you to work 65-70 hours a week. 
Not much fun in the office. 
Compensation flows mostly to those on top. 
If you are not a political favorite, you will probably have to work in your position for at least 10 years before getting promoted.

review_title: Worked for 9 years with the company. JP Morgan
pros:
Internal opportunities to move to other department
Good Paymaster
Nice work environment
Good company values
cons:
work gets monotonous
No opportunities of growth to next level as team leaders don't move up to next level or leave company.
HR don't rehire even if you give 9 years in different departments of the company they only want the last managers opinion for rehire.

pros: The coworkers and managers are like a second family. The enviroment is welcoming and comfortable.
cons:
NETWORKING. Advancing in this company is all about who you know, not how knowledgeable you are. Ive seen first hand, positions opened specifically for a certain person. Multiple employees apply, interviews done, and then that one person is hired. Terrible.  

The metrics are flawed. One quarter of your score card is based on customer surveys. However there is no system to balence these scores to an accurate score. If you get a bad customer survey, youre screwed. Theres no opportunity to advance if you receive low score since it will ruin your whole month.

pros: For new hires you'll learn how to deal with 10 year old technology and processes along with navigating extremely drama fueled cut-throat political bureaucracy doing throw away work that doesn't provide any value to the business, just some senior leader's bonus.
cons:
The benefits are expensive and not comprehensive, costs run to over $200 bi-monthly for a single person so catastrophic coverage is what you really get.
Most times to get promoted or an increase you'll have to throw someone under the bus.  Management manages by blame, so the game is to make sure you have a seat when the music stops.

pros: excellent developmental role to further your career in Private Banking / Financial Advisor / Business Banking as you work very closely with various partners in the mentioned fields. In my branch, private client bankers manage have a direct impact in coaching bankers, sales and client relationships. Those that are dedicated can be very successful and learn a lot through hands on training.
cons: Base pay is low, haven't received a raise in a few years and bonus are a joke.

review_title: Very bureaucratic. Mumbai first, SG and HK are like orphans. Ideally they want outsource everyone to Mumbai.
pros: They pay (yep), the brand also shines on your CV.
cons: Unless you're in NYC (HQ) or in Mumbai (You must be cheap), your promotion prospect beyond associate level is grim esp for non front office roles - this includes software engineers. Ideally they want outsource everyone, except Jamie and the board, to Mumbai. And replace all Front Office staff by robots (urm... Nobody wants be in supportive function like Trade Support/MO/tech/ops, everyone wants to be Front Office). Needless to say, important things that matters to employee never discussed in townhalls (those are military parades where management proclaim their presence) and Employee Survey are probably cooked.

pros:
Great management (this one is big for me)
Great training program (most of the trainers were very competent and experienced)
cons:
Unprofessional environment (the dress code in the line of work I'm at is not respected) 
Some of the people are under-qualified for the job (some of the people I work with don't even have a degree)
The pay is not so good (the health benefits are good though)
It doesn't seem like we will have good career advancement opportunities, at least not in the short term.

pros: The firm boasts diversity and growth opportunities. They did just increase they're non-exempt time away policy granting an additional week's accrual bringing them more in line to attract talent.
cons: Promotions are managed like a carrot dangling in front of a horse. Management is not recruited in line with their diversity statement, and their behaviors are not monitored or effectively weighed and monitored in this regard. Finding a manager who truly respects and celebrate diversity is hit or miss.

pros: good benefits and possibility for flex work arrangements such as work from home, taking extra time off (unpaid) after maternity leave used up.  But it really depends on your manager.
cons: really depends on your individual manager how good your work environment is.  Can vary widely from crazy micro manager to very hands off manager.  Also every year there is something that happens in October time frame when comp is being determined to make it a "bad year" and comp is going to be same (if lucky) or down ….  never have  I heard it is a good year and comp is up ..   I've heard it's better than last year but still comp not great

pros: Some of the nicest, smartest people I've ever met. Always learning, always having fun, always doing great work in an environment that is energizing, collaborative and incredibly motivating. Love it! First place I've worked where I feel truly valued, treated like a grownup and supported on all levels.
cons: f you need hand holding, this might not be the place for you. You have great freedom to design your work plan and flexibility to approach your work however works best for you, which I think is fantastic, but might not work for everyone if you need rigid structure and oversight.

pros: Good team (got lucky), fair compensation, had quite a busy time as this is a Banking Firm which employees candidates in 2:1 ratio (where instead of hiring 2 developers they try and do best with one), unlike consultancy giants in which I worked earlier. You have quite a freedom to move within firms different projects with more challenging roles. In all you have scope to grow.
cons: It mostly depends on the team you are working with. Although its been quite sometime now that I have left the firm but I would still say you need good people that you can build trust upon.

pros: Great benefits. As a personal banker, there's no minimum you have to meet to get your commission cashed out. 1 point = $1. Flexible hours, even when full time.
cons: This position may not last much longer as they are switching their focus to the RB (relationship banker) to focus on sales and balance growth (which a PB doesn't typically do). Sometimes spend more time as a teller than a banker when tellers quit or go on vacation which doesn't hurt your base pay but will hurt your commission. Even as a PB, your focus is to sell your convenience product and not showing enough points/$$, depending on your manager, will show that you're not doing your job well enough.

pros:
-Very well paid.
-Very well established teams / sub teams with very interesting projects.
-Always plenty of work to do even for recent graduates, they never keep us idol.
-Generally a good environment to work at
-Very intelligent, friendly and helpful people - They only hire the best of the best, you'll be working with some of the most intelligent individuals.
cons:
-Terrible coffee!
-Managers / team members can become very busy and sometimes do not have time to provide as much support as should be provided.
-Some political drama, but you'll find some no matter where you go - still a lot better than other places I've worked at.

review_title: Too corporate, employee is just a number
pros: Great benefits, nice working environment, good salary if you know how to negotiate
cons: Where do I start ? I would describe JP Morgan as Marmite. Either you love it or you hate it. If you have worked like me in small to medium companies and you love the family like environment in an office, then JPM is not the place for you. The employee is just a number, processes are way too complicated, IT systems really old and to many systems and tools in place, so you end up log in on loads of different systems to do your job. Very stressful environment. If you are committed and have your own way of doing things you will struggle.

review_title: Great experience working there as they have the best systems and training courses.
job_title: AML Compliance Officer in Newark, DE

cons: Long work hours which impacts most of the workers work life balance for the negative. The daily goals are difficult to achieve on a consistent basis as the work load varies from assignment to assignment.

pros: The company is great as a whole. Complete professionalism and great on technological aspect. People also are highly knowledgeable. No politics at work place

pros: Good benefits, employee centric and opportunities to learn. You will grow if you work hard and be accountable.

Maybe this behavior was just in the line of business I worked under, but many employees seem to have the same opinion.

pros:

review_title: Was proud of my time with the bank

review_title: Great place to work, as long as you're a top producer and have quality management!
job_title: Private Client Banker in San Diego, CA

cons: Too many pointless meetings with partners about leads you've already discussed, and management about compliance.

review_title: Good, Stable Job with Competitive Pay But Not Much Else
pros: JP Morgan is a good place to start a career in Technology, they have a decent graduate programme where candidates are evaluated on potential and not just current technical skillset. Career progression is quite straightforward for the first couple of years albeit every 2 years. People are generally nice although experience could vary dramatically between teams. Work-life balance is similar to other places where people get well established so things like working from home are common for the Glasgow office. Laid-back culture and no dress code. Technology processes are decent to a certain standard but you could see a wide difference between teams. Pension benefits are pretty good with 6% matched contribution and also you get private healthcare in your pay package.  They use a good amount of open source software so a lot of transferable skills relating to technology
cons: Old technologies, legacy or at least very old code (10+ years) which was written a lot by people with no software engineering training. This has resulted in a very brittle code in places and the business never puts massive importance on tackling the core issues of something like this and pretty much always looks in a 1-year delivery and no further. Because of the size of JP Morgan, there is a lot of red tape for certain things so sometimes accomplishing a simple task (e.g. rebooting a box or updating a DB) could feel like a monumental task. Let alone trying to get access to another system.  There is also a total disconnect between higher management and the actual teams. Most of the senior leaders are not based in Glasgow which very much feels like you are in a secondary location with not much to hope for. Moreover, your salary is almost always determined by people who essentially meet you like twice a year which I find quite confusing and irrational. Finally, career progression after the first 5-7 years is pretty much not there for a lot of people. I am not sure if the pay goes that much either.

pros: Recognised in the industry, stability ie not much in terms of redundancy etc

Its definately not a meritocracy, when enquired about how promotions are done etc, was told it was a very complicated process (in my eyes this reads as, u didnt do enough *ss kissing) or simply that you havent made the right impression on someone and whilst they are your Boss you will not get promoted.

Sheer hard work is not acknowledged, but more on how good you are at wasting time by having conference calls, meetings etc! None of these have to be productive, you just have to show you are willing to organise a meeting about having a meeting.
