cons: Economic downturn really weakened some of the opportunities and caused some layoffs.  Company dedicated to meeting bottoms lines so will make decsions in the best interests of shareholders and not employees.

review_title: Great benefits, but not much growth potential
pros: benefits are better here than most places.
cons: Difficult to advance career. JP Morgan Chase is a great place to work when you're starting out or when you're not interested in any more career advancement. If you're new, you'll learn a lot, but as you continue to put in years there, you'll realize that your career isn't really advancing as you'll be stuck doing the same thing basically forever. That can be a problem, but if you're older and don't care to find a new job or move up the ladder, it's a great place to work into retirement.

review_title: Solid company, strong balance sheet, mediocre employee experience
pros: Benefits are good, time off policy is generous, big focus on mobility.  Lots of opportunity if you are willing to move around.
cons: Important decisions are often made so far from the impact of those decisions that bone headed moves are made and employees are left to clean it up.  Extreme focus on cost cutting becomes tiring.  Pay is below average for many. Raises based on meritocracy, but when managers have a 2-3% budget for annual raises including promotions, yearly raises are less than steller even for top performers.

review_title: Overall a great company to work for
pros: Salary and bonus can rise fast if you are prepared to put the work in. Work life balance is overall good considering the industry / compensation - 6-7pm finishes can be a regular occurrence. You are also given a lot of responsibility and encouraged to manage direct reports from an early stage in your career.
cons: Long hours (to be expected), especially during month and quarter ends. Sometimes managerial support is lacking and there is an expectation to just "get on with it".

pros: Good benefits, opportunities for advancement within different divisions.  Pay was fair bonus structure and benefits were good.  Metrics driven
cons: Metrics driven meaning the soft skills and intangible pieces were often not recognized.  Constant environment of change.  Facilities open and close, shifting resources.  Metrics based and often pushed to breaking point through resource attrition only to staff back up when failures were creeping in.  HR was essentially none existent.  Essentially all self serve.

cons: Good starting salaries but once in the pay raise is very slow. You might find yourself underpaid after a few years compared to industry averages. Depending on the division/manager level of support could change.  Can be very bureaucratic and changes could take very long to be implemented.

cons: In my opinion, in the retail division of JPMorgan Chase, there is not much room to advance to other sectors of the financial institution.

pros: It is very hard to identify any positives in this firm. It is bureaucratic, top-heavy and careers can be sabotaged at the whim of a senior manager.
cons: I thought I was just working in a particularly poisonous department as it had around 30% of the people employed there on long-term stress leave. job_title: Vice President Senior Software Engineer in Glasgow, Scotland
pros:
Good office location (Glasgow city center)
Quite good salary in compare with other Scottish companies 
Holidays
Flexible working hours , normally 9-17 , no over hours in my team
Possible to work from home
Possible to change team inside company
Bicycle parking in the basement
cons:
Poor technical expertise on all levels.  A lot of incompetent people even among team leaders.  And even you are qualified enough you can be under the leader who don't know some basic computer science conception.

I know the people who lead the web app project without relation database knowledge. I mean at all.  Can you imagine the code quality?  Moreover in the same time the same person don't understand the principles the object oriented programming. I mean at all even such basic things like inheritance and interfaces. I have never seen such unqualified people. 

Politics and meetings, meetings , meetings. A lot of bureaucracy, you need to get approvals for everything.

Chaotic management, very often project manager in US and available only by conference calls.

No architecture design as class, usually the only criteria "it should work, no matter how" 
No algorithmic challenges, just stupid monkey coding like read from db / write to db and display something on web page. And because of this no learning and development for you.

Nobody care about how good are you as software engineer, it is much better to have strong communications skills.  Looks like they don't need engineers. In the bank they need people who can demonstrate that they do something. So typical bank managers psychology.   Performance review are more important that real work.

Forced visualization as mentioned on of the previous reviewers, yes. If you are linux /unix  developer, you have to live on virtual machine. 

Terrible overcrowded office. Often desks installed literally in the passages.
Once I have seen that 5 developers sitting on the 4 desks. Desks compression! 

A lot of people -> difficult to find vacant toilet.
Difficult to find table in canteen during the lunch time. 

Really I can't recommend this place for experienced engineers. If you want to concentrate on technical tasks this place is not for you. May be it depends the team. But my impression is like this.

Everything under the sun is siloed and out of your control

review_title: I understand why there is a high turnover...

cons:
They expect you to work beyond your hours

There is a strong hierarchy/imbalance between the experienced and the less experienced in my team. Would not be surprised if it’s the same in other teams- it seems everyone has either worked here for ten to fifteen years and knows everyone, or has started in the last two years.

job_title: Operations Summer Analyst in City of London, England
pros: The whole experience was very positive, everyone on my team was supportive and always available for my questions and issues. The facilities are excellent, the location is great, the management is always friendly and open. I could easily chat with someone who is 2 or 3 tiers above me.
cons: Hard to say, I suppose that the salaries are lower than what I have heard from some other interns at other banks, but I don't see any other negative points.

pros: Good intentions to make new comer feel comfortable and good overall training to support new analysts. Interview process might be overdone because you end up taking 20 interviews before a decision is made. This is counterproductive.
cons: It all depends on your team. If your team likes you, more specifically if a senior person on the team likes you, you are in good hands and you will be able to progress. The opposite is true.

review_title: Good place to be in a support function
pros:
Overall focus on doing the right thing.
Internal opportunities exist - but there are many people looking so you might need a good manager/mentor to help.
Good pay, though amounts available (and needs) for pay rises differs by dept.
cons:
Very slow to get anything changed if it involves any support outside your immediate area - and forget about it if you need IT support.
Easy to get lost in such a big organisation.

review_title: Good if you are proactive about your career
pros: Mobility is very much a reality at JPM. As long as you show motivation to learn and transferable skills, you can move around in this organisation from a geographical and role perspective, with very few issues. The culture is quite relaxed as IBs go. Although the majority of people here are smart and driven, they are also easy to get along with and social. The great name on the CV goes without saying.
cons: The compensation could be better as IBs go. Training is not as comprehensive as you would expect at such an organisation - you have to be willing to learn and learn quickly or you will really struggle.

review_title: Great products, company cares about customers. Sadly, not about employees in retail branches. Long hours, low pay.
pros: Products and brand name, bonus coupons for customers make it easy to sell. Benefits are not bad.  I learned a lot and worked with some great people.
cons: Employee experience is a myth.  The experience is long hours, low pay, understaffed and stressed staff. Management makes promises in order to keep you then dangles the carrot forever with no reward in the end.  The hours are the hardest part of all!

pros: Internal mobility, Corporate Offices, good network of smart and collaborative people, socially conscientious and involved in the community, meritocratic culture in most teams (CIB).
cons: One of the least competitive in terms of compensation - salary, bonus, and health insurance. Maternity leave and support leaves a lot to be desired.

pros: One of the best places to work. I like the benefits, work culture, and the organizational policies. There are some leadership training programs which are very helpful for growth of an individual.

cons:
-There's a culture of protecting senior management.

-No one gets fired here. Incredibly discouraging to see 25+ year employees being so disruptive and acting invincible towards younger staff.

review_title: For a huge company my experience was mainly positive

cons: Large company - easy to feel like 'a number'. Management 4+ levels up makes decisions with no understanding of the impact to those doing the work. Redundant and overwhelming documentation / paperwork requirements.

pros: The scheduled work hours are standard banking center hours . Depending on which branch you work at you may work Saturdays until 2:30pm. No Sundays!  Work with great people in a professional environment. Ability to help customers with their finances. Room to advance if so desired. Vacation and Holiday paid time off. Health Insurance. Good place to start working after high school to help you understand the dangers of credit card abuse and control your personal finances. You may learn from helping other people fix their mistakes.
cons: Must be flexible on your scheduled hours to work. If someone is off, you may need to help cover their hours.

pros:

The people mainly ambitious and motivated. There is an atmosphere of intelligence and competence. Many employees have been at the firm for a long time and in different roles.
cons: The firm is very large so many conversations are carried out via internal messaging. It is not uncommon for people who have worked at the firm for years to be introduced to a new team with no idea of what they do.

pros:

The work can be quite dull.

Your workload is entirely dependent on your manager.

review_title: Best place to start out in the IT industry
job_title: Technology Analyst in New York, NY
pros: working on innovative projects with very bright individuals,  flexible schedule, ability to work from home, overtime pay for over 40 hours,  4 weeks off per year, huge networking opportunities
cons: Once you work your way up the chain a few levels, it's essentially impossible to move up further without investing your entire life into the company. Most people hit that wall and leave the company.  It seems that time spent often receives higher praise then accomplishments

pros: Large organization. You can move around inside to many different corners (with many caveats about HR roadblocks). You can get exposure to an incredible number of financial products.
cons: The management culture is rather adversarial. I find that if your management is not good at convincing the neighboring management teams to work with your team, you will not accomplish your program goals. Also, organization is very siloed, so you need to continually work through that to accomplish program goals. Also, the management structure is rigid, which means it's difficult to get your voice heard beyond your direct manager.

pros: There is always a lot of work at JPMC, so you don't need to worry about finding work.  For a good performer hikes and bonuses are good.
cons: In the name of ownership you are practically sold to the company. If an issue occurs at 3am in the night or on sunday you should be available to work on it. And these are pretty regular (nearly every week if not more frequent).

review_title: Strong global platform, management team and balance sheet
pros: Large, global organization that provides an opportunity to work in more than 40 countries across the world.  Has a culture wherein your performance makes room for you to grow within the organization.
cons: Due to the size of the organization, networking is key for mobility.  Unfortunately, processes around moving talent tend to seem either not robust enough or not available for the vast majority.

review_title: Great compensation but be prepared to work an average of 10 hours a day and no time to take any time off

room to move around and promote as long as you are in Ohio or maybe Texas or NY, other than that - forget it.

review_title: Great for resume building, not for a long term career for those with ambition.
pros:
The company has many plus sides to be employed as a technologist. The first of which are the vacation times allotted per employee. Technologists are generally given 4 weeks right out of the gate when they join the company. I don't know if that is the case anymore, but it can always be negotiated in the initial hiring process. 
 
      Additionally, the company provides a very flexible workplace experience, technologist's are often involved in pilot programs that improve the day to day work experience. As such, luxuries such as working from home via remote connections, signing up for virtual workstations that can be accessed anywhere, and blackberry adoption are encouraged.
 
      The benefits that are offered to the employee are great and provide coverage for pretty much anything you can ask for. The system also allows for modifications to benefits when life events such as marriage and childbirth occur so you can easily adapt it to changes in your life. 
  
      With the employer being a large financial institution, your 401k organization is generally very well explained with a great management system that allows you to allocate money to funds at your whim. Additionally, the company will match your contributions up to a certain percentage. Granted this only occurs if the company is doing well. 

    The work culture here provides for a very diverse experience. People have been and will always be very accepting, cordial and professional with you. I have never had or seen a conflict in the office that was not resolved quickly or with either party feeling bitter or resentful of the outcome. 
   
      The bottom line is that JPMorgan Chase is a globally recognized brand, as such, attaching the name and experience to a resume gives you instant recognition in casual conversation and helps your resume stand out should you choose to search for a new job.
cons:
The good talking points above also come with a significant amount of bad aspects as well. Unfortunately the biggest drawback to employment here is found in your advancement and compensation process. The system works on a yearly 3 point scale of either meeting, exceeding, or lacking in your performance goals. Only technologists who rate in the exceeds category can stand any chance of  raise that gives the employee an improvement in their consumer purchasing power while the rest of the employees will get a minor pay increase that will possibly cover the cost of inflation over the year. Cash bonuses generally are small for technologists as they don't bring revenue into the bank and therefore shouldn't be a deciding factor when you choose to work there, no matter what any recruiter says. 
   
    Now this ratings system may sound like a fair process, and in theory it is, in practice however it is not. Only ten percent of the entire bank's population of 180-200k employees can get the rating that puts them into a chance to make more money. The process of identifying and placing those employees into the categories is also a purely political process. Placement is often decided by management levels that are several above yours, thus putting your fate into the hands of someone who you most likely never interact with beyond saying "Hello, how are you?" to at Christmas holiday parties. The end result is that the ratings that are desirable tend to go to the supporting employees that directly report to the executives that decide the ratings as they have the most daily interaction with them. This is a broken system that has been acknowledged as such by several senior managers, however, no real action beyond streamlining the current process is being done to correct the system. 

The end result leads to many talented and hardworking employees that are left in the cold over the years that have left many demoralized to the process and untrusting of management when year end review time comes. 
  
   Aside from the big pain point listed above, there are always the nuisances that come from working with a large corporation:

. Bureaucratic red tape: could be used to decorate the halls for every holiday and there would be plenty left over afterward to use as toilet paper. Your going to need a form for everything you do. 

  Reliance on cheap offshore labor: from a bottom line standpoint, it makes sense, cheap labor provides a lower operating cost. However, the companies that are contracted have high turnover rates and in the technology realm you cant rely on keeping your contacts for long. 
  
  Gatekeeper Employees: this term is used to describe the large number of employees that have built processes or permissions solely around themselves to ensure job security. This is especially bad in the technology realm, you will be working with one or two subject matter experts per application. 

  Unqualified Employees: this happens more than one would expect. Often a technology role will not be filled with an employee with much technology experience or none at all. This is a "filler" employee that tends to do an adequate job after a large ramp up time but does not bring much to the table.  

 Office Space moments: yes, this is a reference to the movie that lambasted corporate America. You will have moments that will mirror this movie directly, there's no avoiding it.

review_title: Only good if you are young and inexperienced
pros:
Ok benefits -- not great and less than "ok" in some cases (like no one in my major metro area willing to accept their dental insurance offerings)

Only need to be in a role for a year before you can move --which is good because any more than a year and the incompetence and nepotism of the management will make you jump from the roof

As long as you play it smart and get the full salary you want when you are hired (don't buy into their talk of "bonuses") you can make decent money here.

Looks great on your resume

If you are fresh out of college HR will come running to your door.
cons:
Some of the worst IT culture I've ever encountered. 

No support for experienced staff --company is only interested in new college grads, off/on-shored contractors and other low-cost low-skill techs. 

Be prepared to deal with "management trainees" who have no clue or experience about IT or digital products but got their job because they could afford to go to an Ivy League school. You will never be offered the same opportunities they are in the company. 

Forget about a promotion: it is almost impossible to get one and you can't advance to a higher level position through job change --you can only make lateral moves. 

Forget about hoping new management will fix problems -- they never actually hire new managers -- they only recycle the old ones into new roles. 

The amount of money being wasted on useless projects and multiple layers of management is dumbfounding. Each year they attempt to "balance the books" by laying off staff in order to cover their losses. 

Be prepared to sit in the human-equivalent of a factory-farm -- they have removed all walls and sit 3x as many people in a space without any semblance of privacy or personal space. It is a cost-cutting measure they attempt to pass off as "innovative." 

Make sure you get all the money you want upfront -- raises are horrible / non-existent and "bonuses" are low and based mostly on favoritism. 

They assess people by "weighted ranking" so only 1 person out of an entire department of 30 may be permitted to receive the highest rating -- regardless of how many people deserve to be rated highly. 

There are so many young (Inexperienced and cheap) workers in IT now that you have to literally train all your coworkers how to do their jobs-- or do it yourself. The company offers no training to these people and there are no global standards to which they are held accountable.

There is no proper quality control in development. 

Senior IT management has a sense of infallibility that prevents them from offering anything of value to customers. 

Tech projects are never thought-out, they are defined on the fly and change direction a minimum of 3x before they get to production. 

There is only a small group of people that management ever listens to and that group is, at best, clueless as to how to fix things and, at worst, complacent and interested in maintaining the status quo. 

If you didn't come from Google, IBM or some other big name-but low-relevance company, you will only ever be a pawn in someone else's empire -- you will never be allowed to advance yourself. 

Best advice: if you are young and inexperienced, take the job to get the company name on your resume but don't stay more than 18 months. Once you hit 2 years you are considered "experienced" and you get pushed to the side to make room for new people.

If your over 35 -- make sure your get out before you are 50 or they will push you out and/or make your life unbearable until you leave.

review_title: Mobility opportunities, career growth aplenty, but overall work culture is just OK

pros: I was able to work my way from a temp data entry job to software tester to business analyst with no college degree or background in computer science, mostly through hard work. Getting noticed coming from where I did took a little while, but once I made my first big step my career trajectory really took off. All the tools you need for career development are provided and mobility is encouraged and celebrated. All you need is the desire, and a little talent. In my line of business, we have gone away from a command-and-control management style towards autonomous teams, and while the road to get there has been a little bumpy, and we aren’t all the way there yet, overall I think the trend to empower the employees had been positive. Generally speaking, my managers serve an admin role but are also supposed to be coaches. Some are better than others at this role, and I do see a little bit of resistance to this change.
cons: It’s easy to feel lost in such a large, global company. As an entry-level employee it took me years to understand what opportunities were available to me, and what the path to Associate or VP looked like. But perhaps that’s due to my unique path more than anything else. Practices vary wildly depending on which line of business you are in, so cross-team collaboration is always challenging. Transparent communication is preached but not always followed. Culture is hit-or-miss, as some teams I have worked with have had a really good vibe, and others make work feel more like just punching in the time clock everyday. As with any large company, your experience will vary depending on your management team and peers.

If you  do happen to be in a bad department... the environment can get toxic... you can tell everyone hates coming into work and everyone openly talks about leaving the department, either internally or externally (this department at JPMC is called JPMIS - JP Morgan Intelligent Solutions).... It got so bad that, at a work happy hour, a former employee (who left JPMC and joined capital one), came to the happy hour with a capital one recruiter to try to help others leave... 

JPMIS was suppose to be department of internal data science consultants, however, it is run by a bunch of bankers who have no technical backgrounds and no understanding of the machine learning and AI space... they cannot lead in this space successfully because they have no understanding of what their data scientists can do and do not talk t the data scientist to learn about their abilities or recommendations. They make promises to internal clients about what work can be done and with a made update, all wihtout consulting the people who are actually going to do the work, the data scientists. It's a place that's bound to fail. They hired a guy from Microsoft to run their AI team and already, within a year he left. review_title: It's the largest bank, with all the pros and cons
pros: It's the largest bank in US - and a brand name that you may love as a consumer, so you may be proud of being employed by it. Benefits and pay are good, not the highest but reasonable. Working with customers in a branch is probably great, but working in IT may be a mix of positives and negatives. If you like being in the company there are internal mobility options and you may find job security for many years, if that is what you want.
cons:
It's the largest bank in US - and as such, there is incredible amount of bureaucracy, administrative work and process issues. Hence, work in many departments and especially IT may be a lot more hectic, busy and stressful than what you would see elsewhere in the software industry. A developer may be ok, but leads and app dev managers experience constant stress, busy schedules filled up with meetings, work with hard-liner project managers with outdated management methodology, and in many cases exposure to a lot of negativism by people impacted by location strategy or stressed out by their managers or deadlines, pushing everyone to complete new urgent tasks that sometimes may not even make sense.

At the app dev manager level there is unlimited amount of meetings, administrative work and urgent emails with ad-hoc requests that you cannot ignore. Being in meetings all the time, your capacity for handling other requests quickly gets maxed out, and with changing priorities you have to pick what will not get done or will be delayed, or you can choose to sacrifice all your personal time and constantly catch up on nights and weekends. At the same time you have to also work with the development teams, so it is critical that you have strong leads that can interface more with the developers, as you would rarely have time for that if you are constantly busy with administrative work and urgent requests by the management. Prioritization and delegation are key, if you have resources to whom to delegate non-technical administrative work. You may or may not get such resources though, which for a large bank is surprising, when all you may need is just couple of more people.

Summing it up, it is a stressful experience that can also be rewarding, provided that you are well-staffed and you if you balance your priorities well. If you come from software development background however, which is the most optimal case for such positions, you may not be satisfied with the amount of administrative vs. technical work. And in the end even if all is good there are also external factors that you cannot avoid, like major org changes and moves of whole departments to different locations. Work in a large bank is very different than software companies or startups that are more focused on the actual work, so it's a matter of what kind of work and stress you prefer, administrative and process related or focus on the technical work.

review_title: Top notch benefits and inclusive environment
pros: JPM is exemplary at embracing diversity and fostering an environment of inclusion; there are limitless resources for networking groups, educational opportunities, and mobility.
cons: As is the case with many large companies, it is just as easy for people to fade into the darkness as it is to shine - in other words, mediocre talent and laziness are often not addressed, at the expense of the employees who are working hard toward the success of the team/initiative.

review_title: Pick your projects well and you can learn/grow.
pros:
JP is not run as 1 big company. While you have "Global Technology", each project is different ... different in the work that you do, different in the way it's managed. If interviewing for JP, please ask about your role and project, not about the company as much (because that's easy to find out). I tend to pick projects where my job role allows me to be a full-time developer and not one that involves any form of support, however a vast majority of projects would require you to provide some sort of support as well.

That said the pros for me were ...
1. Great place to learn - but you have to take the initiative. They are mostly supportive of implementing new ideas as long as you can demonstrate their feasibility and value. If you expect to turn up and learn, that's not going to happen - you'll be given boring work. If you prove yourself ... the good work will follow.
2.  There are good technical training programmes - Most trainings are good - there are a few really bad ones but that's because the training department is trying out new people or have introduced a new training. Participant feedback is taken seriously to help improve future training programmes.
3. I was lucky with some good Managers, they protected me and let me do what I liked doing ... which is code away and they took care of the Politics, not all Managers there are like that.
cons:
Politics!
If your a techie and just want to do your work and be recognised for it ... this is not the place ... There's tons of politics ... TONS .. People will try and drag you down, take credit for your work and show it as their own ... it's a bank .. its competitive .. get used to it. There are good people as well, but they aren't the ones who will grow, they will either accept the situation or leave ... I chose the latter!

Policies are optionally enforced.
While there is a clear comp-off policy, some projects simply don't adhere to it!
They had (officially) arranged the 7 day Project Planing workshop to cover a Saturday and Sunday and there were no comp-offs ... Planning to work on weekends without a need and not giving comp-offs!!! That's just a RED LINE! The problem is there are too many suck-ups who agree to this, so when people who feel this is incorrect speak out, they are told that others don't complain. Just say NO ... It's your right, don't let management bully you.

Compensation
While they do pay well it does not make sense to stay for long, you will find that despite your best efforts, lateral hires with less that half your knowledge or capabilities and often with less experience earn more ... That's the Indian IT job market, the more you switch, the more you earn ... Stay at-most 3 years, then get out .... or learn to suck-up!

review_title: Honest Review of JP Morgan Chase
pros: Good Brand Name, Intelligent Management, Resume Booster, Stepping Ladder, fairly competitive salary.
cons:
Many people who work here ARE the job.  Their job IS their life.  Long, continuos, and strenuous work weeks 60-70 hours are the norm...expect to eat lunch in your cube almost every day.  Inconsiderate email expectations and conference call expectations.  Little to no training.  Very disorganized flow of work. Bureaucracy at every level.  You are essentially owned by the company.  Think Matrix human-battery.   

Honestly, if work is your soul motivator in life, you may very well enjoy working at jpm, but if you have a family, go to grad school, or want a speck of social life for yourself, you really should think twice.  My interviews went very well and they made no mention of the ridiculous work weeks that I have been working.  Make no mistake, I am not lazy, and have no problems putting in extra hours at work but when you get down to brass tax and calculate your earnings based on your hours of work...you are underpaid (even under exempt status).

The training is an absolute joke (you may have experience but all companies handle their product lines differently) and they fail to mention their investment policies which you must adhere to (changing brokers, running EVERY buy/sell past their guidelines).  A lot of people lack true kindness and I sense that many are very bitter about working for the company.  You see a lot of Jamie Dimon cheerleaders....who kiss his .a.ss in hopes of getting that promotion who will promote otherwise, but I think its because upper management sees the trends in dissatisfaction.  Some mid year review surveys that are completed showed that a large percentage of employees were moderately dissatisfied with their positions... not shocking at all. 

Finally, I can say that if you are currently working with a good manager, regardless of your company, STICK with it.  People make A HUGE difference in your happiness at work.  HUGE HUGE HUGE difference.  Taking that extra 10k to work with a-holes is not worth it. 

Good Luck.

pros:
JP Morgan Chase is very conservative and stable company.
They do their best to make calculated and careful decisions.
They have alliances with government in order to secure their interests and longevity.
JP Morgan Chase does the best it can to take care of their customers.
Jamie Dimon is an extraordinary leader and business man. The company is blessed to have captain the corporation.
cons:
The following may not really be considered a con, but rather just how they do business and treat their employees in which case in the perception of an employee may be viewed negatively.
At JP Morgan Chase efficiency is king or at least they strive for it. When I say efficiency does not necessarily mean efficient polices, but rather in organizational structure and how effective you are doing your job. Each year you will give account of your value to the company by listing your accomplishments, goals and more. Basically each year you have to justify why you should continue to work there or that's what it amounts too. They compare this against you and your peers or what is out there in the industry. If it appears that you are lagging behind or this job is just paycheck, then you are candidate to be laid off.

JP Morgan Chase is very self conscious about how the public views them. Reputation is vital asset to their company. A lot things they do must meet the muster of political correctness and legal safeguards. As an employee you will constantly undertake yearly affirmations via computer based training promising to be good an ethical human being, which is not bad thing.

Security is another vital asset the company which they take very seriously, but I wont go into the details of that because of the internal nature of the topic.

Two kinds of people who are successful in this company:
You are very good people person and have mastery in social skills.
You may not be a leader but you are excellent follower adhere to policy and protocol without deviation.
..and both of these two type must not show signs of inefficiency. If you can do that you will either go along way or maintain a stable income.

Chase will try to pretend that they want you to stay after you'd turn in a two weeks notice by asking to see a new job offer just to tell you that they can not match or come close to that offer. Just a show. Banker support getting worse and worse due to massive outsourcing. Technology is good but a LOT of glitches in the last couple of years and seems to be getting worse. Very heavy competition between different levels of bankers where some bankers are not even being paid on certain items but because of the promise of "show what you can do and we'll take care of you" they will gladly take business away from those who otherwise would get paid.
Overall not the Chase I started with years ago...

pros: Brand recognition, smart people, lots of learning resources, most diverse bank on the street.
cons: Working Finance at JPMorgan is the definition of a dead end job. It should be called reporting and not finance. I was in a multitude of finance teams in my time there. They all sucked. The hope is that if you are smart enough you can use networking and connections to get into a front office role. That is what happened for me and I secured a sales gig in the IB. The problem is if you move internally they still do not pay you like you should be getting paid so I left after a year with a front office title to boot. HR at JPMorgan is probably the worst there is at big banks. JPMorgan bleeds highly talented individuals because there is no pathway for actual smart people to get into the roles they deserve to be in. It took me 5 years and an unrelenting attitude, in hindsight I shouldve left JPMorgan much sooner. The name resonates though and it made me stick around longer in a terrible reporting role doing grunt work in the hopes of "making it" at JPMorgan. Mobility is a buzzword there but thats all it is a buzzword. You really have to network your butt off to get out of a finance or controller type of role. Now the big thing, PAY. Pay in these roles is absolutely horrendous and there is not prospect of a pay day working at JPMorgan. Your only option is to leave and come back if you care that much about working for the name. There is no pathway for talent to be rewarded financially wile staying internal. Everything is based on percentages and your increases will top out at 5-6% on total comp at most. That is if you are lucky. This is not just hearsay, this is the experience of 99% of everyone that works in a finance role at JPMorgan. If you really like finance/accounting then go join a small company and be a part of their corporate finance group. You will learn a whole lot more and be much more appreciated

pros:
JPMC is a massive company with so many different areas that you can't keep track of them.  Working in technology is one area can be very different than another area.  I was in an older area that the company had little interest in doing anything with more than simply keeping them running.  So my opinion won't apply to everywhere. 

Pros:
The pay is very good. Generally it can be at the upper end of tech salaries if you have the experience.  But you have to fit in with the manager.  Really, your manager is the only management you'll ever deal with.  Get a good one and life is easy, get a bad one and you'll be miserable.  Movement within the company only happens if you can get in with the manager doing the hiring.  Its all about "relationships".  The jobs are stable for the most part, though quiet, small layoffs happen every so often.  They just don't talk about it.  There are bonuses, and they can be great, but once again it depends on your manager.  Mine was fantastic and gave me great bonuses each year.  Other managers hold that above their employees head whenever there is an issue, and then they'll give out really small ones.  I got about a 10% bonus.  But I spoke to another employee who was being threatened by his manager all the time with his bonus and ended up getting maybe a 3% bonus.  I convinced him to look for another job.  

Another pro is that the company is very diverse.   That's a big initiative and generally works well.

Its not hard to get a job here.  That can be good and bad.
cons:
The biggest issue with the company is the management churn.  My manager had three or four different managers over the course of two years.  It makes starting and finishing projects and long-term initiatives very difficult.  You'd think that managers would pick up where the last one left off, but that's not the case.  Each manager is a silo.  As your go further up the chain, the churn gets worse.  Its not that they necessarily leave, its that they move around.  I think they worst effect is that people are not invested in their area because they know they'll leave eventually.  That means that lower-level managers are the only ones who really work in the trenches.  Talking to them is really depressing.  They know any good initiative has a 50/50 chance of fizzing out.

Siloing exists and is terrible.  Managers are not accountable to one another for the most part.  Upper management doesn't resolve issues between them, nor do they care.  There is no cohesive chain-of-command.  Its very loose and whoever is the most charismatic and clever gets the job done.

HR.  We have an HR?  No, we don't.  Who's my HR person?  I have no idea.  There's someone, somewhere.  Probably not at my location.  Never met a single person in HR when I was hired, nor since.  The internal website is the closest thing I have to HR.

The talent pool is atrocious.  People who have no business in technology are here.  Offshore talent is terrible.  Developers who can barely code get jobs pretty easily.  Why, you ask?  Poor managers, sure, but mostly terrible, terrible recruiting.  Horrifically bad.  Their "recruiters" are offshore talent that have no idea about the job or the location.  They can't schedule things properly, and they can't talk to the candidate properly.  Candidate wants to know where to park?  Forget it.  Directions?  Might as well Google it.  Properly scheduled video conferencing room for an interview?  Good luck even getting a room that has a phone.  The recruiters sometimes get a little belligerent.  Decent talent walks away almost immediately.  Good talent doesn't even bother to apply.  And then onboarding takes months.  Employees show up sometimes without having any sort of equipment on the first day.  JPMC got rid of all the Administrative Assistants, so no one has any idea of who to talk to or what to do or where to go.  Its all handled by some ethereal system in the background.  Want to feel like a cog in the machine?  Work here.  If you're the only team member at your location, then you'll sit there and stare at your cubicle walls for days while things may or may be happening.  If there's an issue, there is little notice and even less done.  It takes individuals who actively chase after things to get someone onboarded.  Hiring someone is utterly embarrassing.  My team has had two people leave almost immediately.

Company culture is fake and empty.  Sure there are lots of initiatives and events and videos and training, but its devoid of real caring.  Its all about optics.  They got rid of the long term people that run the various locations, so the replacements are churners who don't care about making a cohesive group.  Its like a commuter workplace.  People come and go.  Upper management smiles a lot.  The good ones move on quickly.  Pounding sand is the number one activity at Chase.

Morale sucks.  Everyone knows the above issues.  And I had it easier than most.  People put on a fake a smile and try to make things work, but inside they're slowly dying.

But hey, the pay is good, the benefits are decent, and your job is pretty safe.   There's something to be said about not living in poverty.  We often take that for granted.

pros: Great name to have in your CV. Opens doors when applying to MBA's and other jobs. Especially associate roles in finance are constantly asking you to have experience as an analyst in a top tier bank. I guess it serves as an "easy filter". Probably a good company to work for if you are living in the US, but as a European I wouldn't really recommend it.
cons: Very strict structure, the analyst program is a joke because even though you might have experience in another company if you start as a first year analyst you are stuck as an analyst for the next three years. There is no way to become an associate sooner if you do a good job. Not only that but after working your a off for three years you need to do the A2A process (analyst to associate). This is also a joke because they use it as their excuse not to offer you something in case things are not going well in the company. So you could have worked there for 3 years and then if they don't want to promote you, instead of accepting it and being straight forward they use the A2A as the perfect excuse. I luckily quit before the process to go to business school but I have many colleagues that went through it and the whole thing was ridiculous. Everyone is only thinking of him/her self so there is a lot of back stabbing and the work environment is appalling. They pay a HUGE amount of importance to face time and I hated it. If anything someone that can get the work done in half the time should be rewarded higher than the analyst that stays up till very late to send an email so that everyone knows that he is in the office so late... compensation is good but is not very different from other banks. The training in NY is very cool tho. Also I was working in Europe and the American mentality doesn't really work here the same way.

pros:
- Lateral moves: several people are able to move from support function (IT, operations) to FO analyst (in the A2A program) or to the non-IT project team. Risk and Compliance roles are also great opportunities.
- 30-something, even 20-something are a majority of the workforce. Many opportunities to meet and discuss with other departments after work.
- Age is not a factor for promotion to a manager. Some people manage others  that are more than 10 years older.
- Good Brand on the CV. (is what they will tell you when they propose 20% less than Geneva market rate)
- Nice networking opportunities. VP to ED are really accessible, even more so if you join one of the JPM sport team.
cons:
- Technology is a huge pain to deal with, most employees mention technology as THE pain point in their every day life.
- J.P. Morgan seems to value face-time over productivity.
- High turnover at all positions, bankers, operations, IT.
- Salary for support functions is below Geneva standards.
- Bureaucracy, inertia and lack of vision: J.P. Morgan processes are a patchwork of workarounds and temporary solutions that became permanent.
- Heavy focus on metrics that are poorly constructed.
- J.P. Morgan does not invest in technology. 7500 were let go recently even in performing LOB.
Technology people are near-shored in Scotland or off-shored in India. The company invests a lot in client-facing people though (3 people per client instead of usual 1 per client).
- Most jobs in Private Bank are mind-boggingly repetitive (do a report, check the data, validate. Rince and repeat)
- Most tasks are not automated due to politics (oh if it's automated they will reduce our headcounts).

I would have stayed here much longer had I not moved away from the area. If I have the opportunity I will most certainly return to work here to finish out my schooling.
cons: Some customers are rude. However, you cannot control this and it is just part of the customer service world.

review_title: A fairy tale beginning with a not quite perfect fitting glass shoe on the foot ending.
pros: The benefits and pay are great for starting out while your still in college or just looking for something that makes a bit more money to put some away. The employee's you work with are always helpful and you feel like your part of a family with the team you end up on. The paid vacation and personal days are generous without any seniority and are more than your likely to find any where else. Being able to schedule your own vacation days whenever you like and changing them at the drop of a dime is quite nice. The discounts you receive at countless vendors are surprising to say the least how far reaching they are. The training class before starting the job was one of the best that I've encountered.
cons: The size of an organization has a lot to do with the importance you feel your job has in the day to day operations of the overall business. As a financial service representative for J.P. Morgan you won't have any misunderstanding that you can be replaced at the drop of a dime. Policy changes come often and frequent and many times even the management that's above you doesn't know about the changes until a representative is caught by our quality control saying the wrong thing to a customer and they're penalized for it. Survey scores that affect your score card given by customers cannot be reversed no matter how absurd they're request was. You as the representative are penalized (I had a customer ask for a million dollar credit limit with no income) the customer was unhappy that I couldn't help him and left an all 1 rating for the survey. Recently J.P. Morgan had done a mandatory shift bid for all call center locations. The process started late June 2014 and was finalized at the end of July 2014. I was concerned because I school classes that I needed to schedule and my management reassured me that once the schedules were finalized I could submit a school schedule with whatever shift I got and they would work with me. My manager got back to me in early August and informed me 2 weeks before school started that they couldn't accept school schedules now and that I could submit it late October. They absolutely refused to work with me and I was forced to leave to pursue school. The call center that I worked at lost a lot of employees and some of my friends who stayed become increasingly frustrated because of the increase in call volume after so many people left. In mid October my nameless friend put in their two week notice because of the frustration with management and high call volumes every single day no matter what time. They offered my friend part time and said they would work with any request. The lesson learned, when they had tons of people they treat you like a throw away and when they're suddenly hurting after losing so many people they treat you like they always should have. With the year and half I worked there I had 9 different managers cycle through my team. Every manager had different expectations on how calls should be handled. Moving up into management requires you to in a sense drink the cool-aid. What was most concerning was how private information was handled. Employee's are regularly allowed to have their cell phones out and in front of them when your private information is on the screen. There was a manager who actually managed to wear his Google Glass glasses around the building where sensitive information was displayed before finally the site leader saw him one day and freaked out that he had those on where it could record sensitive information. It needs to be said that this managers manager thought it was okay and only had him remove them when the site lead saw them. Employees are suppose to discard any private information that they write down during calls but no one checks anything when your leaving the building so anything could be kept and taken home. With as many security breach calls that I took about Target, Home depo, ext the fact that we could walk out of the building with note pads full of information and no one would check you is absurd and down right negligent. There really are pages worth of things that could to be said and to warn you about before you make the decision to apply at a J.P. Morgan Chase call center. The last thing I leave though is be prepared to handle the public. It's no secret that call center jobs have a bad rap. This job further confirms that very notion. You will take hundreds of calls day in and day out with no time to cool down between interactions. Customers berate you often and you will have to develop a thick skin to handle the interactions.  When you know you are understaffed and know everyday your going to come into a hostile work environment full of angry people who had to wait long periods of time it begins to wear on you even when your not at work. You'll dread going in to it and you will start to think about it even on your days off. It is a good paying job but there is a reason why they give you so much vacation time.

pros: I enjoyed many of the people I worked with and if you have  a strong relationship with upper management, the opportunities to move within the company are greater. The company is good at adjusting to the times and what the customer wants, but unfortunately, change also means cutting cost and many decent mangers find themselves out of management roles and now that relationship you've worked so hard to build is meaningless. The company does a great job training their employees. The online modules help keep branch staff up to date on the latest software, products, and services. The company has some of the best classroom trainers who are enthusiastic and knowledgeable about the company, the subject matter they are teaching, and how to handle various customer and/or employee situations.
cons: The benefits are great, but unfortunately with the amount of turnover, limited staff, and the fast-paced environment, time off is hard to obtain. The pay is tolerable, but the company will leverage the "bonus potential" to new hires. If you are lucky to be placed at a high ranking branch, then yes, the bonus could be great, but the chances at starting at such a stellar branch are unlikely. The company also doesn't tell you that there are a lot of stipulations that have to be met in order to get the bonus; as a result, many new hires will not see that dollar number they had been told was possible during the interview for a while. In the branches, you are required to wear a uniform and employees are expected to pay for their own clothing. New hires get 4 new items and then they are on their own unless you are a teller, then you can order one or two new clothing items on your anniversary, The cost is high and the quality is low for Chase apparel, which is why many branch employees will end up wearing non-Chase clothes and then getting in trouble for them.

review_title: The worst place I’ve worked,  but I learned a lot and grew a lot
pros:
The pay is decent with bonus and they have one of the best time off policies. 
Additionally, it is a truly global company and if you are in the right position you can get a lot of exposure and experience with global projects, other cultures, and world travel.
cons:
I worked at JPMC for three and a half years and have had some form of professional employment for over 20 years with 11 post-college years. JPMC is the only job I legitimately hated on my first day, my last day, and every day in between. They will grind you down and run you into the ground. 
If you are in technology there is an army of staff whose job it is to stop you from doing your job. I was told after I quit by a former co-worker that the average tenure of a JPMC technology staff member is three years.
Every possible technology function is divided into what they call “separation of duties”. You must have excellent communication skills and the ability to build rapport with people or you will struggle when it’s time to do anything because you legitimately need all of these people to get anything done. 
Everything is a multi-month process. You can’t even get a piece of software installed without going through multiple processes to have it approved for use in the bank, “packaged”, then made available. To get software added to the allowable library you have to have approvals from 11 to 20 different groups of people (sequentially) who are under no time constraint to approve or deny your request. 

Be ready to work on weekends. Releases are only allowed on weekends. You are still required to work your 40+ on both sides of the weekend too. 

You are best served by looking for employment elsewhere. 

If you ignore my warning to find employment elsewhere and decide to work at JPMC make sure you get everything you want on the way in. They don’t give raises (though you can get a nice bonus), you aren’t allowed to transfer internally to a higher grade if you work in technology, and promotions aren’t handled by your management or any one in your chain of management. It’s done by a committee once a year (and only once a year). Your boss has to recommend you, several people you work with must write positive reviews about you, and then to actually make it happen your boss needs to play a political game with the managers who are on the committee.  You also aren’t allowed to be submitted for the promotions until you’ve sat at a certain level for a minimum of three years. It doesn’t matter if you are doing the job of a XYZ. You will do that job at whatever grade you are at.

review_title: Loss of Salary to due to "Harmonization"
pros: The majority of its job functions are not terribly difficult or stressful which is the only thing that makes the pay somewhat fair and tolerable.
cons: At some point after numerous mergers and buy outs with other companies such as WaMu for example, employees have had inconsistent titles and salaries. A case in point, I worked for WaMu as a "Workflow" (Supervisor in training) for a number of years and went through the questionable buy out by Chase. Chase basically retained the majority of WaMu's employees and threw them into rolls that were "Company Essential" such as default related and some were placed into rolls that could be considered space fillers. With years of hard work and dedication promotions are typically granted to a select few who have proven themselves. I and many others were legitimately promoted and given a somewhat fair salary which included a small yet appreciated [Annual] bonus for all of our long hours of hard work. As time went on, this must have overwhelmed the system and flooded it with a hodgepodge of inconsistent salaries and made up titles/positions. A process was devised to "level the playing field" called "Harmonization". This stripped away many of our earned and well deserved titles and "Job Levels" which reduced us to hourly employees and bonus ineligible. Since then, annual pay increases have been reduced to little or nothing even though you have met or almost exceeded the expectations of management. This also included the loss of annual bonus payouts. Granted this was not true across the board. Default departments and revenue generating divisions seemed to have had grossly high sums of money at there disposal to compliment their employees with [Monthly] bonus payouts which at times exceeded their monthly salaries based on their performance. Over time the performance standard became conveniently unattainable so that bonuses were no longer paid out in such high volumes and up to now, not at all in most cases. Chase has become larger than life and extremely profitable. The often times forgotten “cogs and sprockets” that make up this vast banking machine called JPMorgan Chase & Co. are now left to fight for promotional positions that are slim to none and most often only available to the favorites of management by not alluding to the postion with everyone. At this point if “Natural Attrition” fails and if you were to look at everything going on with mortgage delinquencies slowly diminishing, smarter less risky loans being issued to customers and investments being geared towards the higher income and successful clients versus the struggling middle class work horses of America, Chase would have no choice but to lay off overstaffed departments or areas no longer deemed relevant such as Fulfillment. Oh wait….. That did happen!!! In conclusion Chase is no different from any of the other “Big” banks out there and even though Chase is a decent place to work it is and always has been geared towards making profits which in turn pleases its shareholder base. Chase places its shareholders first and bases its decisions on what best suites their needs not the needs of its employees, those putting in all the time for peanuts like Barnum and Baileys circus elephants. And we all know what happened to them.

review_title: Great place to start and grow but very political, limited access to products
pros: Extremely high caliber employees with very strong work ethic and dedicated to the customer. Access to experts is unparalleled, I do not ever have a question go unanswered. Very competitive health, retirement, and pension. Many times as a Financial Advisor, I do not have to set my own appointments or waste time at "networking events" that are mostly made of other financial sales people. Other partners (Business Banking, Mortgage, etc) are just a phone call away and are all very high caliber.
cons:
It is a very political landscape, management does not give a damn as long as the money rolls in. If you are starting out, it's a great place to grow and figure out what type of Financial Advisor you want to be, otherwise go somewhere else, especially if you do not want to drink the "blue kool-aid" that management will shove down your throat at every meeting, conference call, and in person opportunity. Be prepared to do a lot of self promoting, don't expect your colleagues to brag about you, they are trying to get ahead as well. The branch banking politics can get out of hand and it become a nightmare game of "telephone" very quickly. This is especially true when things are not going well, always have documentation and be ready to C.Y.A.  

If you want to move into a different department/division, good luck and I hope you have: 1) lots of connections, 2) a stellar reputation, and 3) the ability to get it done without your boss noticing. It's actually easier to go to another firm for 6-12 months and then come back to the division you wanted to go. I have seen several people do this. Do not come to JPM until you can get directly into the department/position you want.

review_title: Company is good but certain divisions are overtly political
pros: Pay scale and yearly hike. Good corporate level trainings.
cons:
Working timing is a con. There is no flexibility and work from home. Analytics being part of ops don't help as being managed by ops guys. It's like a school headed by a principal. Never imagined or experienced in my last 10 years, the kind of meeting that the head of analytics. It's just plain ridiculous. The retention  numbers presented and talked about in every Town Hall are wrong, either the person who creates the summary is very bad in maths or he being instructed to. It's like Shaeed Afridi being 17 always. 
The division is very bureaucratic. Even if the VP behaves badly with female employees and take out gruges against them or people standing up to him, ED is not bothered and so is the line HR. They would go by the VP even after proofs being shown. If that is not enough they would try to push you out.
The onshore partner is also same. And in my tenure I have seen at least 15+ exit from the onshore team. Being closely working with them I know the frustration they share as they would call out in each of our meeting.
Work timing are late and to accommodate onshore we are pushed to work beyond our work timing always. Onshore can go on leave and take work from home and would not work beyond their time but VP, ED expects the offshore team to do the opposite and always accommodate them. if you stand up to them and ask them to let them educate about your problems for the same, all you hear is that "I can't offend them and they are putting in lot of effort so you have to accommodate, even if that means that you cancel your leave or work beyond hours. I just want them to be happy". 
Work is also pathetic. We would have beared it all has the work being analytical. But that too is not. Entire division says it's a big analytics group but hardly 20% of the group does analytics. Many VP are technically very weak but if ask them they would slay a mammoth with bare hands!!!

The harder you work to make more money, the faster they can cut it if they feel you are making too much

pros: Pays well, may be good resume entry, if you want to coast along, easy to get buried in the thousands.

Bell curve ratings for staff stopped in name only, still the lower rated staff get riffed or are at greater risk of.  Typically there are 3-4 redundancy rounds a year, this leads to massive uncertainty across the board.

pros: Decent pension, 401K, and vacation. Not a bad place to work if you can handle the fact that you  could be let any minute.

pros:

pros: The people I worked with were largely intelligent, friendly, and good at their job.  There was very little in-fighting among workers within my group.
cons: Compensation was well below comparable positions at many other companies, which eventually led to the exit of the most talented staff members.

job_title: Lead Engineer in City of London, England

cons: Being a huge corporation, sometimes things are a bit disorganized. It takes a while to get infrastructure set up and support can be a pain.

pros: Loved working for WaMu.  It was when the company was bought and sold for peanuts that it hurt.  The company was good and treated the employees well.
cons: Sub-prime mortgages were the pitfall.  The company had a strong consumer banking divison; the mortgage division was extremely challenging.  Toward the end (during the financial meltdown of 2008), the company was in a frenzy.

pros: Excellent work culture. JPMC has zero tolerance policy against any integrity, ethical  behaviours. Employees across the different blocks are co-operative and a good place where female employee has equal opportunities as his counterpart.
cons: As such none, my experience in 3 years has been that this organization values human value. There are few things wwhere company doesn't have clear policy, e.g. when you working on off days there is no official comp-off and it all depends on Manager's decision.

pros: regular paychecks and big bank holidays
cons: if you aren't a protected class or a diversity quota filler, then run to the nearest exit. Only the chosen are supported in this culture and they are not required to perform in order to succeed and advance. Suckers like me, who believe merit and experience will win out are absolutely wrong and can not win in this culture.

review_title: Opportunity to work with world's top bank.
pros: A lot of options available in JP Morgan. Both in terms of business domain as well as technical skills. They have almost all types of lines of businesses a bank in the world currently has. They are using almost all technologies ever invented.
cons: They have good mobility programs and  internal job positions to retain talent. But all such options only work if you have a stong network and connections with your seniors as well as other project stake holders.

review_title: Subpar compensation ruining an otherwise good company
pros: Large bank. Brand cache. Interesting work. Working with some very bright people.
cons: Compensation, compensation, compensation. Raises are minimal to non-existent. Folks who've been with the bank for a few years will very likely make as much or less than new hires. Loyalty is not rewarded. Lots of politics. Benefits are being eroded, especially health, but that might be a common issue across all companies.

review_title: Steep learning curve but definitely worth it
pros:
Overall this was a great experience, with an American culture:
- plenty of opportunities and challenges, even more if you are willing to relocate,
- actual meritocracy, provided you are in good terms with your line of management,
- easy exposure to senior management.
cons:
- Hard and long working hours,
- Projects release phases can be very stressful (some people can really overreact to minor issues),
- Depending on teams: politics,
- Salary below Geneva average.

review_title: Great place to launch a career
pros: Mobility, opportunity and the satisfaction of working for a globally recognized brand. The company offers a very generous benefit package, the best in the industry in my opinion.
cons: Some of the technology/software can use a face lift. Also sharpen up on you salary negotiation skills.

review_title: Working at J.P. Morgan is an intense but challenging and interesting experience.
pros: The company operates a strict meritocracy, so hard work and skills are fairly rewarded. The pay and vacation benefits are excellent, and the culture is definitely changing for the better.
cons: The work-life balance can be difficult to manage, with heavy hours required. Problems related to coworkers or the office environment can be slow and difficult to solve.

review_title: This was a ground up, newly built mission critical data center that needed experienced DC people

cons: This was only a short term contract and once finished with the build out, the contract ended and they had no other openings available.

review_title: J.P Morgan has been a great place to work.  I feel that I have been able to grow my career at the company
pros: J.P Morgan has been a great place to work.  I feel that I have been able to grow my career at the company.  They have good benefits and try to take care of their employees.  Their pay is above average.
cons: With all large companies comes politics.  JP Morgan is no different.  Moving up the corporate ladder is sometimes difficult within the company.

pros:

High referral expectations

Minimal pay raises

pros: Great stability when other banks were shutting down 4 to 5 years ago. As far as keeping a job that is.
cons: When you try to move up or into other departments within the company, usually it's way more people applying for a small number of jobs which makes company movement more difficult than i imagined.

pros: Through acquisitions and restructures, the Mortgage Banking division has managed to retain a hardworking group of technical employees who work tirelessly to meet goals.
cons: The pace never relents which creates frustration, burnout and job dissatisfaction.  Additionally, the healthcare coverage changed dramatically in response to the Affordable Care Act, placing a substantial greater share of the costs (plans with high deductibles, co-pays, high out-of-pocket limits) to employees.

review_title: Depends heavily on the team you join

The company does have diversity initiatives (LGBT, Women) do not seem to impact day-to-day employee behaviour on the ground in Asia. 
On the Sales & Trading side, technology was clunky due to legacy systems. Definitely a laggard vs other investment banks in this respect when I was there.

pros:
1. Nice and Friendly Environments
2. The people know each other by their first names and the culture promotes you to know everyone very well
3. Time allotted for a project was sufficient for completion of the task

cons: Hours are too long so it affects the work life balance. More branches are needed so that it would make it easier to compete with bigger banks in the state.

review_title: AWM program gives you a good knowledge of different lines of business. Good training
job_title: Asset and Wealth Management Program Analyst in London, England

pros: Great Employee Benefits, Great Products, Great People.  Really enjoyed the job.  It was easy to sell when you truly believed in the products.

pros: enjoying the culture and putting business always first. great people to work with and great opportunities for someone who is motivated

review_title: Very bad  to make a career for Software Engineers!!!
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Houston, TX
pros: If you are at your late 50s and want to retire, this is good place to settle  as a final career stage...they give 5% match for 401K and you will get so many coworkers at your age :)
cons:
1) Too many managers. If one project has 5 software engineers who do the actual job , there will be 7 managers who talk about this project and make a living.
2) The 7 managers schedule several meetings to make them visible for upper management and they waste your entire day!
If you are real software engineer who want to make a great career, DON"T COME HERE!!!
3) Too restrictive and software engineers scramble around to get access to even development environments. You may waste 3 weeks until 12 managers approve your access to a development server where you deploy your code and test.
4) There is no enough resource for software engineers to play around and make a research on emerging technologies. They will give you a desk top computer with cloud based windows with 4-8GB memory. Same as your manager who only use it to run MS word and Excel. Your machine freezes when you run two IDEs together.  SQL DEVELOPER + IntelliJ will kill the machine and you can't check your email unless you close your IDE where you are in the middle of writing code.
5)  Managers don't care about your career growth! and no significant salary increment even if the company is claiming to be a trillion dollar company. Who cares if you are not part of that share..
6) Too many re-organizations and your may not finish your project before you are assigned to a new project and start learning it from scratch again..

..I can't write all here.
If you are real tech savvy and want job growth, I strongly discourage you!! You will even loose your hands on experience you got elsewhere...

review_title: The worst place i've ever worked in my LIFE - unskilled/tedious work
pros:
Company name on your CV is literally the only perk

Rigid, corporate hellhole.

If you want to be a wannabe banker holding your coffee cup in the morning but without any of the knowledge or skill then this job is ideal for you
cons:
I wished there were more reviews of this place before I joined it so i could have turned it down at the time  but I will write this so that anyone thinking about joining knows the truth and doesn't bother.

JP Morgan has been on a very huge recruitment drives past 4 years hiring left, right and centre with minimal vetting for job posts in CIB or asset operations. This isn't REAL JP Morgan like you'd get in London...it is not a prestigious site at all and many in the company look down on the roles here.

There is obsessesion with front office because those are better paid jobs but also they look down on people who have an ambition to move to front office (all jobs there are middle office) . This is what happens when you don’t have a real qualification. Work is distinguished between those who do operations and those who bring in money to the bank. And this is how the class you as people in this company. 

The  Bournemouth and Edinburghs site are is the equivalent of an India call-centre for operations which they seem to have not yet outsourced abroad. The work is dreadful, boring, mundane. A few tech apps could easily replace 50% of the workforce in this office and the workforce is not educated  or trained enough to improve their working environment and make it more internally effective. 

One building is new and the other is in laughably poor condition despite being young. It doesn't represent JP Morgan at all and it is so poorly maintained compared to other places and competitor places i went for interview

Ageist workforce -  managers only hire young candidates and badger you over age when you join.  Huge bias towards hiring mainly privately educated individuals 

Office is at edge of city and you have to pay for parking - makes leaving on time difficult because of traffic in area 

Some staff are bullies. Very backstabbing environment with mostly two-faced people who won’t let their guard down because every situation is so political. 

It’s so corporate and stuffy, there is nothing FUN about working here. 

Arranging time off is a nightmare and even if you try to book months in adv you might still not get it - depends on office politics and cover which is non-sense because you're legally entitled to take time whenever YOU decide to

Out of date dress code because none of the roles are client facing. Awful tech systems and desks. No consistency with risk assessments towards seating plans regarding posture/comfort or even office facilities such as anti-glare screening or  gelled mousepads to keep comfortable during work hours. They are refurbishing one of the buildings to sell it later as they will eventually close it and downsize jobs after brexit. They are saying otherwise but the building is not that old but quality of it was poor. 

Low pay in line with other competitors such as standard life, barclays etc. They do not pay bonuses to all and the bonuses are as low as £500 when you consider how many people work an average of 10/11  hour days. Salaries are also low and opportunities to move around within the company are limited or go through an extreme vetting process WITHOUT any pay increase. You cannot transfer to another area in the company and receive a pay rise. 

There is a very cringey amount of sucking up between associates/vp's and their bosses ED's and MD's.

No flexible working - leaving on time/at 5pm is frowned upon. Even if you turn up early say 7/8am it doesn't count for anything. They work you like a dog. 

I've seen staff plead to be contacted about work when they're taking a holiday and it's just facepalmingly embarrassing - this place does not care about you at all and they will replace you with a moments notice.
